courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Why Culture Matters
courses.description: This course is an introduction to culture, with an aim to broaden students' understanding of humanities in general as well as the relevance of culture to contemporary society. The course explores the relationships among cultural appreciation, cultural representation, cultural continuity and cultural criticism; it also examines how related knowledge and practices in the humanities are valuable of enriching, on the one hand, students' own value system and lifestyle, and, on the other hand, the overall betterment of society, particularly in the digital age of globalization. The course is not theory-based, but its purpose is to expose the students to the diverse strains of cultural thought and practice that are relevant to contemporary society, particularly that of Hong Kong, China and Asia. Relevant contemporary issues will be drawn extensively to explain the values of the humanities and the need for knowledge of cultural studies in the societies of Hong Kong, China and Asia.The course covers four sections to explain the breadth of knowledge that can be applied to understand how culture works. The four sections include (1) basic introduction of cultural studies as an interdisciplinary field, (2) media representation in popular culture, (3) memory, history and modernity and (4) community, urban culture and critical pedagogy. The four sections show the trajectory of applying a cultural studies point of view to understand why culture matters in today’s fast changing world. The Chinese and English sections of the course will select from a total of 22 sub-themes to discuss the role of culture to art, technology, education and humanities.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Students will understand that culture is important in the building of a better society.

• They will also gain the ability in critically analyzing the diversity of values and interests in society.

• Students will be able to draw on a number of disciplinary origins within areas of the arts, humanities, and social sciences to appreciate the richness and the usefulness of interdisciplinary approach.

• Students will gain a critical respect for local histories, traditions, and appreciate the value of culture in humanities.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduction to Public Humanities

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 402

courses.description: This course introduces students to the basic concepts and practices of public humanities, an emerging field that examines the influence of the humanities in the public sphere. It guides students through the ways in which humanistic thinking and inquiry can impact community engagement, collective cultural history and memory, policy-making, and the cultivation of empathy. Organized into three sections—Visions, Paths, and Experiments—each part focusing on different dimensions of public humanities, the course begins by exploring the conceptual foundations of public humanism, emphasizing the importance of curiosity, generosity, and collaboration. As the course progresses, students engage with real-world case studies that demonstrate how humanities initiatives can reshape culture and society. Students will also experiment with designing a small-scale collaborative project, which allows them to transform their public concerns and humanistic inquiries into concrete outcomes. These projects serve as a starting point for their further development within and beyond the programs of public humanities. The course is designed for students interested in leveraging the humanities to enrich public culture.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:*

1. *Analyze and Develop Public Humanities Projects:*

* Evaluate and curate small-scale public humanities projects, understanding their impact on community engagement and public scholarship.*

2. *Communicate Scholarly Research Effectively:*

* Utilize digital platforms to articulate complex ideas in a clear, accessible manner, effectively reaching and engaging diverse audiences.*

3. *Collaborate Effectively in Diverse Teams:*

* Work collaboratively to integrate diverse perspectives, assess team dynamics critically, and manage project challenges efficiently.*
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Part A: Visions**

* *Week 1: Rethinking the** **Humanities for a Better Future**

* Students will be introduced to the development of the humanities, focusing on the challenges in universities and exploring new directions.
* Core readings:

* Wang Hui, “The Humanities in China: History and Challenges.” *History of Humanities* 5, no. 2 (2020): 309-331.
* Judith Butler, “The Public Futures of the Humanities,” *Daedalus* 151, no. 3 (2022): 40-53.

* *Week 2: Being a Humanist: Learning to Be Curious**

* Students will learn about the tradition of humanism, especially the role of curiosity in everyday life as a counter to instrumental logic.
* Core readings:

* Sōetsu Yanagi, “The Beauty of Miscellaneous Things,” in *The Beauty of Everyday Things* (London: Penguin, 2018), 27-57.
* Perry Zurn and Dani Bassett, “A New Vantage Point,” in *Curious Minds: The Power of Connection* (Cambridge: MIT Press, 2023), 1-18.

* *Week 3: Being a Public Humanist: Learning to Be Collaborative**

* Students will explore the importance of generosity and collaboration as a counter to solipsism and competition.
* Core readings:

* Kathleen Fitzpatrick, “Reading Together,” in *Generous Thinking*(Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press, 2021), 82-131.
* Patricia Leavy, “Methods for Working with Nonacademic Stakeholders, Teams, and Communities,” in *Popularizing Scholarly Research* (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2021), 1-11.

* *Part B: Paths**

* *Week 4: Looking Around Us**

* Students will examine how public concerns are integral in shaping the environment and community.
* Core readings:

* Phillip Meuser, “How Architecture Supports Lives,” in *Public Humanities in Architecture* (Berlin: DOM Publisher, 2023) ***OR***
* Julie Sze et al., “Stories from the Field: Public Engagement through the Environmental Humanities and Allied Disciplines.” *Resilience: A Journal of the Environmental Humanities* 5, no. 2 (2018): 49-73.

* Tutorial Case Study:

* Suzannie Leung, “Socially Engaged Arts: Luke Ching’s Practices for Hong Kong,” *The International Journal of Social, Political and Community Agendas in the Arts* 14, no. 4 (2019): 25-35.

* *Week 5: Learning From the Past**

* Students will explore how history and memory are shaped and maintained through scholarship with a public dimension.
* Core readings:

* David Graeber, “The Myth of Barter,” in *Debt: The First 5000 Years* (London: Penguin, 2012), 21-41. ***OR***
* Simone Bohn and Pınar Melis Yelsalı Parmaksız “Researching Mothers in Public and Political Life,” in *Mothers in Public and Political Life* (Ontario: Demeter Press 2017)

* Tutorial Case Study:

* Constance Crompton, “SemantiQueer: Making Linked Data Worked for Public History.” In Schwan, Anne, and Tara Thomson, eds. *The Palgrave Handbook of Digital and Public Humanities* (Palgrave Macmillan, 2022), 89-104.

* *Week 6: Enriching Public Policy**

* Students will be introduced how humanists enrich the direction and quality of policymaking, especially through introducing alternative rhetoric, ideas, and styles.

* Core readings:

* Sarah Dillon and Claire Craig, “Introduction,” in *Storylistening: Narrative Evidence and Public Reasoning* (London: Routledge, 2021). ***OR***
* Judy Segal. “Public Discourse and Public Policy: Some Ways that Metaphor Constrains Health (Care).” *Journal of Medical Humanities* 18, no. 4 (1997): 217-231.

* Tutorial Case Study:

* Doris Sommer, “From the Top: Government-Sponsored Creativity,” in *The Work of Art in the World: Civic Agency and Public Humanities* (Durham: Duke University Press, 2013). ***OR***
* Mara Cristina Caballero, “Academic Turns City (Bogotá, Columbia) into a Social Experiment,” *The Harvard Gazette* (2004, March 11)

* *Week 7: Cultivating Empathy**

* Students will be introduced to how the humanities can offer empathy to the public.
* Core readings:

* Susan Lanzoni, “Introduction,” in *Empathy: A History* (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2018). ***OR***
* Xu Bin, “Introduction,” in *The Politics of Compassion: The Sichuan Earthquake and Civic Engagement in China* (Stanford: Stanford University Press, 2017).

* Tutorial Case Study

* Junxi Qian and Eric Florence, “Migrant Worker Museums in China: Public Cultures of Migrant Labour in State and Grassroots Initiatives,” in *New Theoretical Dialogues on Migration in China* (London: Routledge, 2023), 22-40.

* *Week 8: Reading Week and Midterm Paper Submission**

The midterm paper enables students to consolidate their learning from previous lectures, while also assisting them in completing their group projects and final papers. Students are required to engage with the course materials by addressing the following sections, with each section being approximately 300 words, for a total of no more than 1000 words:

* What aspects of your everyday life spark your curiosity? (Week 2)
* Describe the roles and responsibilities you typically assume in a collaborative project, such as:

* Studying community and/or environment
* Conducting historical investigations
* Analyzing public policy
* Communicating with diverse groups in the public sphere. (Weeks 3 to 7)

* The use of ChatGPT is permitted. You must, however, explain how ChatGPT was utilized in the preparation of your midterm paper, including details of the prompts given to the AI and how its responses facilitated your work.

* *Part C: Experiments: Curating** **a Small Humanistic Investigation for the Public**

* *Week 9****: Finding****, Reading****, and Curating** **Scholarly Works Online**

* Under the guidance of the instructor, students will collaborate to read and curate a humanistic investigation using recent academic journal articles on public issues such as:

* Environment and Sustainability
* Community and Inclusiveness
* Public Health and Aging
* Urban Development
* Labor Condition
* Mobility (e.g. Migration and Tourism)
* Inequality of Technology (e.g. Digital divide and AI debates)
* Other topics (after discussing with the instructor)

* Students will learn to interpret the latest research articles and curate them in an engaging direction for public consumption. The selected articles should be interdisciplinary, encompassing both humanities and non-humanities scholarly work, aimed at drawing public attention and enhancing public literacy and intelligence.
* The curated content will be refined in subsequent weeks and prepared for online publication on the social media account of the public humanities program.
* Core readings:

* Jamie Smith, “Undergraduate Research and the Public Humanities: Workable Futures.” *Pedagogy* 22, no. 1 (2022): 61-78. ***OR***
* David Rowe, “The University as a ‘Giant Newsroom’: The Uses of Academic Knowledge Revisited,” *Culture Unbound* 9, no. 3 (2017): 228-239.

* Tutorial exercise:

* Students will be grouped and tasked with developing a tentative area or title for their project.

* *Week 10: Impactful Stories on Digital Platforms, for Public Literacy**

* Students will be introduced to various forms of presentations and platforms, including *Public Books* (<https://www.publicbooks.org/>), *The Conversation*(<https://theconversation.com/global>), *AEON* (<aeon.co>*)*, *Gushi (Story**Studio* <https://storystudio.tw/>*)*, and various new media and community newspapers. Students should refine their storytelling based on their previous humanistic investigations.
* Core readings:

* Jacob Burg, “Pedagogy of and for the Public: Imagining the Intersection of Public Humanities and Community Literacy.” *Community Literacy Journal* 14, no. 2 (2020): 130-137. ***OR***
* Jefferson Pooley, “The Impact Platform.” *Parameters* (2017).

* Tutorial exercise:

* Students will decide on the framing and strategies for publishing their work to the public and consider potential stakeholders with whom they can collaborate.

* *Week 11: Consultation Week (Attendance required)**

* *Week 12 (and 13): Group Presentation**

* Students’ projects, as initial attempts in public humanities, will serve as references or prototypes for further exploration in other modules of the program. For example, a group focusing on public health in Hong Kong might develop their presentation into a humanities research project, public art project, independent film, YouTube video, etc. The skills for different cultural formats are expected to be acquired by students in other modules of the program.

* *Individual final paper (1500 words):**

* Each student is required to write a reflection paper on the group project in which they participated. The paper should include the following sections:

* **Improvement Opportunities:** Discuss how the group project could be enhanced, including aspects such as theme, content, time management, and presentation style.
* **Alternative Approaches:** Describe other directions the project could have taken.
* **Learning from Peers:** Identify the best projects in the class and discuss the strengths that can be learned from them.
* **Future Endeavors:** Explain whether you are interested in continuing and revising this project or if you prefer to explore other topics for future projects.

* *Utilizing ChatGPT:** Describe how ChatGPT was used to assist in the writing of this paper.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Research Methods in Public Humanities
courses.description: This course offers an overview of research methods in Public Humanities, and equips students with the essential research skills, cultural sensitivity, and critical perspectives required to navigate this dynamic landscape. Through an immersive exploratory journey on research methods, students will engage in pilot research for a collaborative hands-on project, embodying the driving ethos of this course: engagement, praxis, and reflexivity. In this endeavor, students will explore diverse qualitative and digital research methods for investigating, documenting, and sharing stories, histories, and other forms of cultural mediation for community engagement.This course is designed to foster an interactive and dialogic learning environment that cultivates peer collaboration and exchanges of insights. Building on the conceptual foundations laid in CURE1004 Introduction to Public Humanities, this course provides students with the practical skillset needed to unlock the transformative and empowering potential of humanities-based research that nurtures and nourishes the community.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 Do Meaningful Research: Making a Difference
Students will be introduced to the epistemology, methodology, and an overview of research methods in Public Humanities.

Week 2 Think Out of the Box: Research Topic
Students will engage with themselves, academic literature, and understand the importance of contextualization. They will also engage with their peers to start designing a community-engaged research project.

Week 3 Be Sensitive: Ethical Considerations in Doing Research
Students will develop cultural sensitivity in evaluating the ethical implications of their research project. They will work towards adopting the best practices with research ethics in mind.

Week 4 Listen! Do an Interview, Learn from Lived Stories
Students will learn the essentials of conducting interviews, focus groups, and ethnography for community engagement. They will also practise being empathetic through role-play exercises.

Week 5 Be a Treasure Hunter—Researching in the Library
Students will equip themselves with the skills needed to be resourceful researchers, making the best use of library resources for their projects.

Week 6 Be Open-minded—Gathering Insights from the Community
While survey is not a common research method in the Humanities, students will learn the fundamentals of conducting surveys to gather insights from the community they are engaging with. They will design effective survey questions.

Week 7 Be Observant & Reflexive & Imaginative
Students will explore the art of observation as a research method. They will learn techniques for conducting systematic observations to better understand the community context and dynamics relevant to their projects. Students will practice being attentive observers and taking field notes.

Week 8 Be Tech-savvy: Workshop on Data Visualisation and Digital Scholarship Research
Students will acquire the basic knowledge of digital research tools and data visualization techniques. They will lean how to use these for data collection, analysis, and visualization to support public scholarship and storytelling.

Week 9 Reading Week/ Fieldtrip
Students will join an off-campus cultural tour to engage with the city and the local community.

Week 10 Be Receptive: Consultation
Students will discuss their project proposal drafts and share any challenges they are facing with the lecturer and/or tutors. They will receive feedback to improve their proposals.

Weeks 11 & 12 Be Eloquent: Presentations
In these two weeks, students will share the proposals for their community-engaged projects, backed by concrete pilot research data. They will also exchange insights and provide constructive feedback to their peers.

Week 13 Be a Good Storyteller: Writing a Research Paper
In addition to communicating their research to broad public audiences, students will learn the essentials of writing a readable and impactful research paper.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Text and Image: a Critical Analysis
courses.description: This course is aimed at the students beginning their encounter with theory, in which they will learn the fundamental components of cultural criticism in terms of textuality and contextuality. Here the " text" is broadly defined as cultural artifacts, which includes filmic image, literary and historical narratives, social and everyday life experiences as well as media representation. The course materials are selected to give the students the basic information and guide to understand the object, the purpose and the method for cultural criticism. Topics discussed include intertextuality, defamiliarization, dramatic monologue, metaphor and montage, narratives and space-time structure, psychoanalysis and stream of consciousness, reader-response criticism and genre studies.

\* Literacy in different forms of visual, verbal & textual expressions, understanding how meanings & affects are constructed in different media forms & genre

\* Cultural appreciation and cultural criticism

\* Communicative and presentation skills

\* Independent and contextualized research skills

\* Board-minded but strong in critical evaluation

courses.description: Despite their long history, the influence of many great religions can still be recognized in our contemporary world. This course is designed to introduce students to this influence of religion in various aspects of our modern life. It will explore a variety of religious themes such as religious myth, symbol and practice, as well as current religious issues in ethics and politics. In order to illustrate the religious presence in our contemporary life, we shall examine these themes by looking at cases of films, activities and practices that can be easily seen in the world today. It is an introductory course and expects no prerequisite knowledge from students.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge outcomes

1. To become familiar with the basic themes of the field of religious studies

2. To develop an understanding of the key religious issues in the contemporary world

3. To be able to reflect on the relationship between religion and the human condition in the contemporary world

4. To be able to engage in analysis of religious phenomena, taking into account of the key themes and issues involved.

Attitude outcomes

1. To develop a critical yet sympathetic attitude in understanding religious phenomena.

2. To develop a sensitivity to religious dimension of human life.

This course then focuses on the study of the chief elements of religious beliefs and practices. These will include the phenomenon of religious experiences, myths, symbols, rituals, prayer and beliefs.

courses.title: Chinese Culture and Its Religion
courses.description: (UGEA1450 is double-coded with CURE1122.)  The aim of this course is to help students understand the basic religious characteristics of Chinese culture and the relationship between religions and the daily life of Chinese people. It also helps students to appreciate the richness and diversity of the Chinese traditions and acquiring essential preparation for more advanced courses in the area of Chinese culture and religions. The course is divided under the familiar categories of Buddhism, Taoism, Confucianism, and Popular religion. These traditions are, by no means, discrete and mutually exclusive. It will be demonstrated that they overlap and interact with each other through a variety of confluences and conflicts. Students will also be introduced to some primary source of the Chinese traditions including both textual and fieldwork data.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGEC1450 or UGEA1450
courses.learning_outcomes:
(1) understand the basic religious characteristics of Chinese Culture

(2) appreciate the diversity of Chinese Culture

(3) able to have a comprehensive understanding of the essential characteristics of Chinese civilization through a cross-disciplinary approach

(4) learn to appreciate and evaluate, by way of an integrated approach, their own cultural heritage from a broad. historical, social and intellectual perspective.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: World Religions
courses.description: (UGED1400 is double-coded with CURE1123.)   This course provides an introduction to some major religious traditions in the world from a phenomenological and historical point of view. Topics include Christianity, Judaism, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, Daoism and Local religions etc.. Through the study of religion in different cultures, this course seeks to broaden students' horizons and widen their academic experience.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken UGED1400.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:

(1) Students will be able to understand world religions in their historical settings and contemporary contexts of modern living; globally, locally and in their many facets

* (2) Students will be able to engage in a* critical analysis of religions by the methods of the humanities and social sciences

Skill Outcomes

(1) Students will be able to develop their skills associated with data gathering and direct observation; organizing it, understanding it, and presenting it.

(2) Students will be able to develop their skills in cross-cultural understanding and intercultural literacy.

Attitude Outcomes

(1) Students will be able to develop their ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of religious traditions especially those one does not belong

(2) Students will be able to develop their sensitivity to ultimate concern and religious dimension of human life

(1) Indian Religious Traditions:

Indus valley civilization, Vedas, Upanishads, Karma-Yoga, Bhakti movements, Theravāda Buddhism

(2) Chinese Religious Traditions:

The Three teachings--Confucianism, Taoism, & Buddhism (Mahāyāna & Vajrayāna), local religions

(3) Abrahamic Faiths:

Judaism, Christianity, Islam

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Study of Christianity
courses.description: (UGED1520 is double-coded with CURE1124.)   The primary aim of this course is to provide students a broad and comprehensive understanding of the Christian faith through introducing its characteristics, traditions, history, scripture, theology and ethics. It helps students to analyse critically the various forms of Christianity and appreciate the richness of the Christian religion that exerts so great influences on human civilizations. Through interdisciplinary dialogues, this course also aims at helping students to see how the Christian faith understands and deals with problems, predicaments, political and ethical dilemmas of humanity.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge:

* To achieve proper understanding of Christianity as a global phenomenon and some of the representative manifestations of Christianity in various local contexts.
* To obtain a comprehensive knowledge of the major aspects of Christian faith, especially its views of the meaning of human life.
* To have a basic understanding of the methodology involved in the multidisciplinary study of Christianity.

Skills:

* To be able to use the analytical framework and hermeneutical tools for the academic studies of the religious phenomena related to Christianity.
* To be capable of relating what have been leant from this course to some other academic disciplines.
* To have the ability to reflect critically on one’s own cultural and / or religious tradition.

Attitudes:

* To treasure the value of human life and be sensitive to the related ethical responsibilities.
* To appreciate the diversity within particular cultural and / religious tradition.
* To become more respectful to others’ religions, worldviews and values.

courses.title: Interpretation of Art
courses.description: Targeting at students with no prior knowledge of art history, this course introduces students to methodologies and theories currently used by art historians and curators to analyze and interpret works of art. The course covers a range of themes such as representation, expression, form, style, Formalism, Iconography, Marxism, Gender etc. Using modern and contemporary Chinese art as examples, the course will equip students with transferable and analytic skills, knowledge of modern and contemporary Chinese art, aesthetic sensibility, and theoretical literacy, encouraging them to apply these methods and knowledge to the study of visual art.

1. Demonstrate knowledge of the basic approaches and methodologies in art appreciation
2. Understand of key issues of the visual arts in modern and contemporary China
3. Demonstrate facility in research skills and familiarity with primary and secondary sources
4. Demonstrate the ability to analyse critically works of art by adopting appropriate theories and methodologies
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I

Introduction to the language of visual art and formal elements, definition of art, and key concepts related to beauty in Chinese and European arts.

Part II

Introduction to the development of modern and contemporary Chinese art, ranging from the Republican period to the 21st century, exploring a range of artistic practices, including ink painting, oil painting, sculptures, and installation and covering themes such as modernism, art institutions, and globalisation

Part III

Introduction to the theories and methodologies currently used by art historians and curators to analyse and interpret works of art, including Formalism, Iconography, Biographical approach, Marxism and the Social history of art, Feminism, and Semiotics.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduction to Cultural Management
courses.description: Cultural management is frequently perceived as a new terrain both for the acknowledgement of the role of culture in driving economic and social development, and for the dissemination of managerial thought to arrange and plan cultural entities, facilities and services. This course first aims to facilitate students’ understanding of the rising discipline of cultural management, which is embedded in the transformative understanding of culture and the on-going global movement that highlights culture-led development. Second, it introduces the managerial approach to cultural assets, initiates students’ understanding of the relationship between arts management and the market system and government policies, and imparts the preliminary knowledge for the management of the arts. Third, it displays a spectrum of major issues in cultural management, such as cultural policy, cultural organizations and institutions, venue management and event programming, heritage, conservation and cultural tourism and cultural creative industries. The breadth of the discipline as indicated allows students’exposure to the basic cultural management concepts and strategies.
courses.learning_outcomes: In terms of knowledge enrichment, students are expected to achieve the understanding of the discipline of cultural management, including its objectives and values, its relationships with the transformative understanding of culture, the on-going global movement that celebrates culture-led development. Other major issues will also be covered. Students are expected to understand preliminarily the operation of art businesses and cultural organizations in connection to market values and government administrative systems. In terms of management training, students will learn practicalities such as cultural managerial principles, planning strategies and basic skills, issues, challenges and limitations specifically for the arts and cultural resources. Discussions are largely based in the local context, supplemented with overseas and Chinese cases, with an awareness of the variances across contexts.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I. Cultural Management as a New Discipline
This part introduces the historical and disciplinary background of cultural management.

1. Understanding Culture: history and theory
The first section presents an introduction to the course. As cultural management is embedded in the discourse of culture, this section explores the concept of culture and highlights the theoretical transition from the anthropological idea of culture as values and practices to the understanding of culture as a capital and resource. The emergence of the cultural economy concept will also be discussed.

2. Understanding the Discipline of Cultural Management
This section discusses the evolution of the discipline of cultural management over the past four decades, that is, from arts management, to cultural administration and management. It introduces the objectives of the discipline; the way that this discipline has been gradually accepted and subsequently widely practiced; and its closely related neighboring disciplines. It also discusses the professional role of cultural managers; their differences from artists and creative workers are highlighted.

3. Cultural Management in the Globalization of Culture-led Development
This section examines the discipline of cultural management from the view of the global movement that utilizes culture as a driving force for development. It discusses a set of concepts that emerged in the recent decades, such as creative industries, creative classes, cultural planning, culture-led urban regeneration and creative cities. It provides the historical background for the evolution of these concepts, discusses the issues and challenges that they encounter and their application in various local contexts.

Part II. Managing the Arts
Art management is considered a traditional realm of cultural management. This part focuses on the managerial approach to the arts. Section 4 investigates the disciplinary relationship between cultural management and traditional management, and the peculiarities of art management. Sections 5 and 6 introduce preliminarily the management of two major art sectors: performing arts and visual arts. Sections 7 and 8 are concerned with cultural management in the social environment and discuss its connections to art marketing and administration.

4. Managerial Approach to the Arts
How to manage the arts? How is art management different from the traditional study of management? This section introduces the managerial approach to the arts. It explains the disciplinary relationship between cultural management and traditional management, and discusses how art management crystallizes the philosophy of both management and the arts. Art management covers four main managerial issues, namely, strategic management and planning, human resources management, finance and accounting and marketing and consumer behavior. The empirical implications of art management’s peculiarities are also discussed.

5. Introduction to Performing Arts Management
Performing arts is one of the major subjects in art management. This section introduces the concept of performing arts and its management. It discusses basic performing arts programming strategies and its relationship with theatres and other performing art venues. Some basic modes of organizing performing arts and performing art agencies are discussed.

6. Introduction to Visual Art Management
Visual art is another major subject in art management. This section introduces the concept of visual art and its management. It discusses various types of visual art spaces and agencies (e.g., museums and art galleries), introduces their similarities and differences in concepts, functions, operational modes, policies and evaluation modes.

7. Art Consumption and Art Marketing
This section focuses on the concepts of art consumption and art marketing. It discusses the determinants of artistic values and the processes of creating and diffusing artistic values in the market. It covers the issues of art consumer behaviors, market prices, cultural business branding and positioning and art sponsorship, from both the consumption-and production-oriented perspectives.

8. Cultural Administrative Structure
The government plays a significant role in cultural development. This section attempts to investigate government and public administration in cultural affairs, its administrative structure, patronage and state-based arts funding agencies. Some recent tendencies (e.g., corporatization of government entities in cultural affairs administration) will be examined withHong Kong as the major context for study. Cultural administrative structures in China, Taiwan and the U.S. as well as their institutional reforms will also be examined.

Part III. Major Issues in Cultural Management
This part introduces some major issues in the cultural management discipline, including cultural policies, cultural organizations and institutions, cultural venues and events programming, conservation, heritage and cultural tourism, as well as cultural and creative industries. It will introduce students to the concepts, operational principles and their management or planning strategies. Cases from various contexts will be studied.

9. Cultural Policies
This section introduces the definition of cultural policies and the process of cultural policy making. It presents a preliminary discussion regarding the way that cultural policies affect cultural development. Policy issues such as government subsidies, cultural industrialization tendency, government’s promotion of art values and cultural censorship will be addressed. Cultural policies from various contexts will be examined.

10. Cultural Organizations and Institutions
This section categorizes art organizations based on their basic operational mechanisms. It models the growth of firms in the cultural field and describes the sequences and stages as well as determining factors. It also discusses the governing structure of cultural organizations (e.g., the board structure and its impact on organizational missions and strategies), cultural funding and patronage, volunteer management and management control systems. A global perspective is introduced for examining the connections between local and international cultural organizations.

11. Cultural Venues and Event Programming
This section introduces the concept of cultural venues, facilities and districts as well as events planning and programming. Students will be introduced to the theoretical discussions regarding the role of cultural venues and events in cultural development and their functions in fostering local culture. It also introduces basic principles of and strategies for cultural venue planning and strategies for event programming,including cultural venue administration, public engagement, event promotion as well as public-private partnership.

12. Cultural Tourism and Heritage Management
What are cultural tourism and cultural heritage? What is their significance and inter-relationship? This section defines and discusses their roles in culture-led urban regeneration. It also introduces the basic strategies for programming cultural tourism and explains the significance and methods of heritage conservation. The second half of this section introduces an integrative approach to cultural tourism and heritage management in order to develop cultural destinations, using European, American and Australian casesfor study.

13. Cultural and Creative Industries
The last section will investigate the theory and practice of cultural and creative industries. It will examine the historical context in which the concepts of cultural and creative economy have arisen, its adoption as public policy from the UK and worldwide and its reception and development in Asia Pacific region. It will look at policies and strategies as proposed and developed by various countries in the region with particular emphasis on China, Japan, Korea, Taiwan and Singapore and evaluate the development in Hong Kong.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Cultural Policy and Development
courses.description: The course is an introduction to the nature, functions and making of cultural policies. Making references to examples of local and international cultural polices, it studies the relationship between the making of cultural policy and the infrastructure of power, the ideological influences behind the making of cultural policy. It also studies the latest trends in cultural development and its relationship with policy-making, and the impacts on the development of arts and culture, with particular references to the local context. The course also includes a practical aspect of drafting and developing institutional policy as part of the studies in cultural management.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to learn about how cultural policy is composed, its scope and structure, and the ideological components behind it within the context of the infrastructure of power, and to understand the impact of cultural policy in shaping the development of culture. The course also intends to equip students with the skills of drafting institutional cultural policy, which is essential for the development of a cultural institution.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. General introduction

This section gives an introduction to the various definitions of cultural policies, with discussion on its impacts on cultural development and its relationship with the social and political infrastructure.

2. Culture and Power

This section investigates how political, social and economic powers affect the outcome of artistic creation, both in terms of the formal artistic languages and the modes of production and mediation.

3. Historical Background

This section uses examples from Europe and the United States to trace historically how various modes of governance were introduced and study the political expectations and social values hidden behind these policies.

4. Globalization and Cultural policy

In the 21st Century, cultural industry is recognized as an important economic and social force. Large scale cultural projects are implemented all over the world to promote cultural tourism and creative industry. This section takes a critical look at this global trend and reviews its cultural and social impacts.

5. Cultural policy in Hong Kong

This section informs students of the infrastructure for cultural development in Hong Kong, studies the history and development of the arts within the governmental structure, and traces the various stages in developing a cultural policy for Hong Kong.

6. Institutional Policy

Cultural institutions usually have their own cultural policies to set their visions and objectives for their long term development. This section studies the various types of institutional policy, with an emphasis on helping students to learn to prepare an institutional policy paper.

7. The Ecology of Culture

This section investigates some of the core cultural values in contemporary society, with emphasis on the Hong Kong context. It also introduces an ecological approach to cultural development, and reviews the success and failure of the existing cultural policies within the public and private sectors.

8. Cultural Development and Operation in China

This section studies another model in which cultural development is strongly managed by the government. Taking Shanghai as example, students will study the process of organizing exhibitions in China and ideological thinking behind this bureaucratic system.

9. Language of the Bureaucrats

In Hong Kong, the government has tremendous influence on the ways arts and cultural programmes are implemented. This section investigates how the civil servant culture and the language they apply shape the content of the policy produced, and consequently affect the course of cultural development in Hong Kong.

Case study: Culture Heritage Commission

10. West Kowloon Cultural District: Mega Cultural Project

Focusing on the development of the West Kowloon Cultural District project, this section reviews the original proposal, public responses, and the subsequent reaction of the government, with the intention to investigate the governmental modes of thinking and strategies in actualizing cultural projects.

11. Alternative Space and Community Action

As a reaction against governmental dominancy in cultural development, different types of alternative cultural institutions and groups are formed. This section investigates the potential and limitation of various types of non-government run organizations. It also studies the strategies of community groups in working with and against the government in fighting for a more nurturing cultural environment.

Case study: Hong Kong Arts Development Council, Para site Art Space

12. Cultural Policy and the Future of Cultural Development of Hong Kong

This section looks into the future cultural development of Hong Kong, its relationship with China and other regions, and discussion the problems and possibilities for positive development.

13. Review and Discussion

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduction to Cultural Studies
courses.description: Through examining texts, artistic forms and discursive practices that reflect and produce different cultures, students will take part in delineating the working definition(s), methodology and critical awareness of the subject. Concepts such as multiculturalism, diaspora, hybridity, globalism/localism, transnationalism will be discussed. Emphasis will be given to Hong Kong culture as a basic reference point in its contact and interaction with other cultures.

2) Skill Outcomes
Independent academic research on new concepts
Analytical writing on cultural concepts and approaches of cultural criticism
Presenting ideas through reading and cultural analysis

3) Attitude Outcomes
Proactive in learning and research

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Cultural Studies of Space
courses.description: This course will examine the subject of space from the cultural studies perspective. The objective is to understand how space as a cultural phenomenon relates to matters of ideology, social class, nationality, ethnicity and sexuality. The course will investigate the ways in which meaning about space is generated, disseminated and produced through various practices, beliefs and institutions, and how understanding of space is embedded in the political, economic, or social structures within a given culture. Examples of space making and manifestation will be taken from both Hong Kong and overseas.
courses.learning_outcomes:
In terms of knowledge acquisition, students are expected to understand how space is defined and constructed and their impacts on the development of society in terms of the make-up of our regional, national and global orders; their role in the shaping of cultural practices, expressions and ideology; their relations to production and enterprising and hence their role in the shaping of our identity, taste and values as well as economy and policies. In terms of values and skills, students are expected to develop critical ability in analyzing the diversity of values and interests, inter-cultural sensitivity, a balance view of local and global issues, literacy in understanding different visual and textual meanings and forms and the ability to appreciate the importance and significance of the inter-disciplinary nature of space studies.

知識探索方面，預期同學可瞭解空間如何界定與構建，並明瞭其：對地區、國族、全球的秩序組成等社會發展的影響；在文化習性、表達、意識形態形塑中的角色；與生產及企業的關係，從而瞭解其在身分、品味、價值以至經濟及政策形塑中的角色。價值與技巧方面，預期同學可發展出分析不同價值及興趣的批判能力、文化互動中的敏感度、本地及全球議題的平衡視角、明瞭不同視覺及文本意義暨形式的理解力、領會空間研究的科際性質的重要性及含義之能力。
courses.course_syllabus:
Course content:
1. Space and place
This introductory section will define the scope of investigation of space as cultural practice and will examine the concept of space versus place and their differentiation in the theories of Casey, Tuan and de Certeau. Key reading: Certeau, Michel de. The Practice of Everyday Life (Berkeley, California: University of California Press, 1984).

2. Public and private
The second section will examine the concept of public versus private space and the consequence of politics and identity. The issues of making and privatization of public space and public art will be discussed. Key reading: Habermas, Jürgen. The Structural Transformation of the Public Sphere (Cambridge, Mass: MIT Press, 1991).

3. Consumption and production
This section will look at the meaning and impacts of space of consumption versus space of production. The shopping mall and office building will be taken as case studies to understand their cultural roles in the modern society. Key reading: Sorkin, Michael (ed.). Variations on a Theme Park (New York: Noonday Press, 1992).

4. Representation: film and literature
This section uses film and literature to understand the issues of representation of space: how space is presented and understood through audio-visual and textural media. Key reading: Blanchot, Maurice. The Space of Literature (1955) trans Ann Smock, Lincoln: University of Nebraska, 1982).

5. Visual art, architecture and planning
The section will examine space manifestation in the realm of visual art including architecture and planning. The transition from the Renaissance pictorial space to the Modernist architectural space will be discussed. Key reading: Damisch, Hubert. The Origin of Perspective (Cambridge, Mass., London: The MIT Press, 1994).

6. Memory and fantasy
This section will study the function of space in constituting the collective consciousness of memory and fantasy. The issues of heritage conservation and construction of theme parks will be examined. Key reading: Eco, Umberto. Travels in Hyperreality (Picador, 1987).

7. Narrative and history
This class will study the role of space as interpretation of narrative and its function in contributing to our historical understanding of the city. Key reading: Schama, Simon. Landscape and memory (London: Fontana Press, 1995).

8. Urban and rural
This section will study the dialectics of development of space between urban and rural; their rise and fall in the social and economic transformation of societies. Key reading: Soja, Edward W. Postmetropolis: Critical Studies of Cities and Regions (Oxford: Blackwell, 2000).

9. Landscape and gardens
This class will study space as manifestation of landscape and gardens: how they become symbols and microcosm of social constructs. Key reading: Weiss, Allen S. Unnatural Horizons: Paradox and Contradiction in Landscape (New York: Princeton Architectural Press, 1998).

10. Space and gender
This section will explore the gender issues in space – how space acquires meaning in sexuality. Key reading: Colomina, B. Sexuality and Space (Princeton, 1992).

11. The economics of space
This section will study the economics in the making of space, in particular, in the real estate, urban renewal and development sector and their impacts on society. Key reading: Lash, Scott & Urry, John. Economies of Signs and Space (London: Sage, 1994).

12. Postmodern space
This section will investigate meaning of space in the transformation of social and cultural paradigm – the shifting of modern to postmodernism. Key reading: Harvey, David. The Condition of Postmodernity (Oxford: Basil Blackwell, 1990).

13. Cyberspace
This last section will study the significance of cyberspace as new form of spatial construct – the issues of politics, identity and power – and how it might change in future. Key reading: Virilio, Paul. The Lost Dimension (New York: Semiotext(e), 1991).

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Culture and Travel
courses.description: There are two characteristics in culture: regional (space) and accumulative (time), and is the way to acquire various cultural experiences from different space and time. From the cultural perspective, there are different levels of travel: from "tourism" for pleasure, "travel" for different purposes, like study, works, business or military, to "journey" for life experience and eternal truth. This course aims to provide theoretical reflections and historical analysis on the relation between culture and travel, and in particular, the wide range of symbolisms of cultural experience of travel. It will be able to help students explore the process of crosscultural interactions as well as the knowledge of cross-cultural management in travel.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students should gain a much more critical and reflective understanding of travel experience and its power implications to both the hosts and the guests.
2. Students should be able to survey major social cultural theories on travels.
3. Students shall get to learn travel that is culturally innovative and socially responsible through the course’s fieldtrips.
4. Students shall learn to become a historically reflective and culturally sensitive traveler or responsible citizen when they travel around the world.

courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

- identify, describe, and analyze the technical aspects of film as art.

- deeply analyze in diverse ways of critical thinking on film/media, such as the views of genre, auteurship, and spectatorship, and grasp the ways to utilize these different analytical frameworks for the writing of film criticism.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1. Introduction to course
Film:
1. Christopher Nolan, Memento (2000)
2. Alison Klayman, Ai Weiwei Never Sorry (2012)

Readings:
1. 李歐梵，“影評現狀”，《我的觀影自傳》（北京：人民文學出版社），200-207 。
2. 戴錦華，“文化研究與電影”，《電影理論與批評》，22-24。

Week 2. The Narrative Approach: Film Language and Narrative
Films:
1. Orson Welles, Citizen Kane (1941)
2. Simon Barrett, Jason Eisener, etc. V/H/S/2 (2013)

1. Seymour Chatman, “What Novels Can Do that Films Cannot”, Film Theory and Criticism, 6th, 445-460.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Celebrity, Stardom, and Hong Kong Popular Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2245 is double-coded with CURE2007.) Celebrity culture is generally understood as a cult full of short-lived trends and inconsequential fan behaviour. We seldom consider, however, the powerful influence it has over our cultural identities. This course examines how the interplay between celebrity culture and the cultural industry shapes cultural identity with case studies from Hong Kong as the major scope of study. Starting with a brief history of Hong Kong celebrity culture from the 1980s to the present day, the course offers an entry point for students to understand the intricate relationship between the media and celebrity culture, encompassing a wide range of cultural icons and phenomena such as action film actors, cross-media megastars, and YouTube micro-celebrities. Each case study will engage with key concepts in celebrity culture, such as star-text, commodification, authenticity, extratextual reading, and participatory reading. The course proceeds by introducing the critical perspective of cultural studies in making sense of representation politics, public culture, fandom studies, and the diverse modes of intimacy in the digital age. Overall, students will gain an understanding of celebrity culture and how identities are thus produced, promoted, and commodified in the wider arena of media and popular culture.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of the subject, students will be able to:

* **Define and explain** the connotation of celebrity culture, stardom, and popular culture in contemporary society, and the genealogy of discourses development of Hong Kong popular culture over time.
* **Understand** on how cultural identities are shaped by the interplay between celebrity culture and the popular culture industry.
* **Employ** a selected range of methods to study the development and formation of celebrity culture and infer the meaning of such process in the Hong Kong context.
* **Reflect** on the impact of celebrity culture on the formation of cultural identities.
* **Demonstrate** the intersectionality of celebrity culture and the formation of cultural identities locally and globally.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Class 1 Introduction: Why Does Celebrity Culture Matter?**

* Introducing the basics of celebrity culture and the importance of studying celebrity and stardom
* Outlining the development timeline of Hong Kong celebrity culture from the 1980s to the 2020s

* *Class 2 Star Image and Star Text: Bruce Lee**

* Analysing the production and consumption of film stars and their star image
* Synthesizing the critical concepts of ‘star-text’ in celebrity studies and ‘textual analysis’ in cultural studies
* Assessing Bruce Lee as a star text in relation to the concept of ‘representation’
* Integrating the case of Bruce Lee with the identity formation of Hong Kongers as modern citizens

* *Class 3 The Social Phenomenon of Stars: Leslie Cheung**

* Discussing the critical concept of ‘extratextual reading’ in celebrity studies
* Assessing Leslie Cheung as a star text in relation to the concept of queer stardom and posthumous fame.
* Integrating the case of Leslie Cheung with the identity formation of Hong Kongers as cosmopolitan

* *Class 4 Discussion Panel (I)**

* Students will work in groups to create a presentation about their favourite Hong Kong film star. Presentations should be submitted online via Blackboard.
* Each group will then be assigned to review another group’s presentation. They will analyze the assigned work and apply one concept from Class 1-3 in their critique.

* *Class 5 Cross-media Megastar (1): Anita Mui**

* Interpreting the concept of ‘commodification’ in cultural studies in relation to Anita Mui's on-screen persona.
* Demonstrating the influence of popular music on stardom and celebrity culture

* *Class 6 Cross-media Megastar (2): Twins**

* Theorizing ‘celebrity-commodity’ in celebrity studies and mapping the culture industry in the 2000s
* Examining how the industry of popular culture in Hong Kong gives rise to cross-media megastars
* Evaluating ways in which the stardom of the cross-media megastar influences the formation of Hong Kong cultural identity

* *Class 7 On the Politics of Authenticity: ‘Real’ Celebrity and Reality Shows**

* Discussing the concept of ‘authenticity’ in celebrity studies and media studies.
* Critiquing how television channels have produced stars and singers via talent shows and reality shows from 2000s to 2010s
* Comparing two local TV shows, Minutes to Fame (殘酷一叮) and Good Night Show – King Maker (全民造星) in their creation of ‘ordinary celebrities’

* *Class 8 Discussion Panel (II)**

* Students will work in groups to create a presentation about their favourite Hong Kong singer. Presentations should be submitted online via Blackboard.
* Each group will then be assigned to review another group’s presentation. They will analyze the assigned work and apply one concept from Class 5-7 in their critique.

* *Class 9 Stars, Consumption, and Public Culture (1): Anthony Wong, Anson Lo, and Jeremy Lee**

* Discussing the concepts of ‘celebrity consumption’ and ‘participatory reading’
* Examining the ‘campness’ of the star image of Anthony Wong, Anson Lo, and Jeremy Lee
* Integrating the practice of ‘queer reading’ to complicate concepts of celebrity culture

* *Class 10 Stars, Consumption, and Public Culture (2): Denise Ho, Kay Tse, and Charmaine Fong**

* Demonstrating celebrity consumption as a fundamental part of public culture
* Exploring how celebrities engage with fans in the public arena
* Assessing the star text and fandom of Denise Ho, Kay Tse, and Charmaine Fong in relation to the identity formation of Hong Kongers from 2010s to 2020s.

* *Class 11** **Stars in the Era of Platform Culture**

* Examining the availability of media platforms (e.g. Instagram, YouTube) and convergence media culture
* Evaluating changes in the celebrity culture alongside convergence culture
* Reflect on how convergence culture influences the formation of Hong Kong identity
* Case study: Serrin/ Leung Ka-yan (梁嘉茵) and Trial & Error (試當真)

* *Class 12 Discussion Panel (III)**

* Students will work in groups to create a presentation about their favourite Hong Kong micro-celebrity. Presentations should be submitted online via Blackboard.
* Each group will then be assigned to review another group’s presentation. They will analyze the assigned work and apply one concept from Class 9-11 in their critique.

* *Class 13 The Trans-Asian Influence of J-pop and K-pop Culture to Hong Kong**

* Evaluating the trans-Asian influence of J-pop and K-pop on Hong Kong celebrity culture in terms of industry, star images, and styles.
* Case study: Cookies and Mirror

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Understanding Digital Humanities
courses.description: This course introduces students to theories and practices of digital humanities. The aim is to explore the technological shaping of human cultures through practices. Students will learn about the history, the rationale, the benefits, and the challenges of digital humanities. Each week, the lecture will introduce the historical trajectory of the fields’ development, its new configurations with the emergent technologies (such as Natural Language Processing and Language models). From week three onwards, each lecture will also include a short section focused on introducing a DH tool. Tutorials are dedicated times for students to put theories to work and to experiment with the DH tool of the week. By the end, students will have the skills to create, analyze, and critique digital humanities projects. Students will also learn to critique the field's practices and contributions. This course will explore the intersection of technology and culture and discover how students can shape the future of humanities research.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* **Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:***

* **Understand the fundamentals of computation and explain its possible connections to humanistic inquires***

* **Engage critically with debates about quantitative methods and data visualizations in humanities in both verbal and written form***

* Develop basic competence in using tools of DH through tutorial discussions and project demonstrations.*
courses.course_syllabus:
1. **What is DH? (Week 1)**

* *Readings: Eric Weiskott, “There Is No Such Thing as ‘the Digital Humanities’,” *Chronicles of Higher Education.***

* *In-class activity: Browse the CUNY DH sample projects and summarize what you see. <https://wiki.commons.gc.cuny.edu/Sample_Projects/>**

2. **The “Digital” in the Humanities (Week 2-4)**

* *Week 2: What is “Digitality?”**

* *Readings:** Benjamin Peters, “Digital” in *Digital Keywords.*

* *Melissa Dinsman, “The Digital in the Humanities,” LARB. 2016. https://lareviewofbooks.org/article/digital-humanities-interview-bethany-nowviskie/**

* *\*Every week from week 3, the course will introduce a fun tool for d****oing** **digital humanities. The tutorials will include students’ demonstrations of the tool introduced in the preceding week plus a critique of the tool. The team of students responsible for introducing a tool are required to explore the tool as much as possible – discovering all its functionalities and problems.**

* *Week 3: What is “Data?”**

* *Readings: Daniel Rosenberg, “Data before the Fact.”**

* *<https://projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/eswg/files/rosenburg_-_rawdata.pdf>**

* *Fun tools for DH:**

Voyant-tools.org (basics)

* *Week 4: Distant Reading**

* *Readings: Franco Morreti, “Conjectures on World Literature**

* *Fun tools for DH:**

timeline.knightlab.com (example of timeline: <https://vinepair.com/wine-colonized-world-wine-history/#11> )

3. **The “Computational” in the Humanities (Week 5-7)**

* *Week 5:**

* *Readings: excerpts from** **Gemini technical report (2023) and OpenAI technical report (2023)**

* *Text generation** before LLM. Numerous text generators have been available. You can ask one to write a paper for you in postmodernist style. Poets have created randomly generated poetry to show that machines, too, can be literary. (Example: <https://nickm.com/memslam/five_word.html>)

* *Fun tools for DH:**

Orange (a free app for manipulating text)

<https://orangedatamining.com/getting-started/>

* *Week 6:**

* *Readings: excerpts from** **Gemini technical report (2023) and OpenAI technical report (2023)**

* *Text generation** depends on the development of Natural Language Processing and Large Language Models. LLMs, like OpenAI's GPT-4, are trained on vast datasets, enabling them to understand and generate human-like text with remarkable accuracy and fluency.

* *Readings: Ted Chiang, “ChatGPT Is a Blurry Image of the Net,” *New Yorker***

* *Fun tools for DH:**

Concordle (a similar document analysis tool)

<https://folk.uib.no/nfylk/concordle/>

* *Week 7: Computational Studies of Text**

* *Readings:** **Michel et al., “Quantitative Analysis of Culture Using Millions of Digitized Books.”**

* *Fun tools for DH:**

Chat Analyzer (a smart phone app for analysing chat data. You need to pay 20HKD for using it).

* *More advanced tools for DH:**

Chinese tool, <https://smarthanzi.net/en/index.php> and Markus: <https://dh.chinese-empires.eu/markus/beta/> (only google chrome, and it is for marking up a text)

4. **DH as critique, or what Humanists can do for AI research(week 8-9)**

* *Week 8: Humans Behind the Machines**

* *Readings:** Mary Gray and Siddharth Suri, “Introduction” from *Ghost Work*

* *Fun tools for DH:**

Flourish.com (a platform for data visualization).

* *Week 9: Humans Affected by Machines**

* *Readings:** Chapter 1 of Meredith Broussard, *More Than Glitch*, page 1-6.

* *Fun tools for DH:**

Scraping google news.

<https://tools.digitalmethods.net/beta/googleNews/>

* *Final project consultation.**

* *Week 10 Guest Lecture (Perspectives from a ML Scientist)**

* *More advanced tools for DH:**

Communalytic (data collection; topic analysis; network analysis; sentiment analysis)

5. **DH and Cultural Politics (week 11-13):**

* *Week 11: Against DH**

Reading: Alan Liu, “Where is Cultural Criticism in DH?”

Tara McPherson, “Why are the Digital Humanities So White?”

* *Week 12:** **For DH**

Reading: Mathew Kirschenbaum, “What is ‘Digital Humanities, And Why Are They Saying Such Terrible Things About It?”

6. **Environmental concerns of DH (week 13):**

* *Energy consumption, mineral mining, the global GPU supply chain and its waste have all significant and largely unseen environmental impact.**

Reading: Bender, et al., “On the Dangers of Stochastic Parrots,” FAccT(2021)

* *Final project presentations (week 14-15).**

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Body Politics and Representations
courses.description: This course explores issues related to the representations of the human body in various cultural forms, including literature, cinema, drama, photography, advertisings, and medical discourses etc. We critically interrogate and examine the logic and implications of these representations through close textual and contextual studies. With the help of contemporary cultural theories, we engage in theoretical discussions about the complex issues related to the body, covering topics of identity, society, gender, and sexuality. The aim of the subject is to help students to understand the cultural myths and the rich meanings of the human body, so that we can most intimately examine the formation of our identity and value system.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to understand how our cultural and social orders are made up of and maintained by representations of and various forms of discipline on human bodies. Students should be able to critically understand the many interests invested on the body, and critically evaluate the meanings of such diversity of values. With close studies of literary, film, and art texts, students are expected to develop literacy in visual and literary expressions. Reading theoretical texts from different disciplines, students are also expected to appreciate the richness and the usefulness of interdisciplinary approach

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Meaning in Motion: Dance, Theater and Culture
courses.description: Dance is historically entwined with many cultures around the world. Dance has certainly played a significant role of ceremony, rituals, celebrations and entertainment since before the birth of the earliest human civilizations. This course provides an understanding of the history, evolution, and universality of dance as an art form. Further, viewing dance as a social and cultural practice, the course aims at analyzing dance semantics and meanings in gestures, the interrelationship of dance and space, theatrical design and costumes, the formation of a dance to its social background, customs, as well as concepts of the self representation and embodiment in their dancing.  In particular, students will have opportunities to experience learning the gestures encoded symbolic meanings with narratives of dances. To demonstrate a physical understanding of a variety of dance forms, this course allows them to explore the pleasure of creative process of choreography in workshops.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Articulate the role of dance in social, cultural and historical contexts.
- Lean the knowledge for interpreting the differences among world dances, rituals and traditions.
- Decode world dance semantics & cultural symbol
- Understand the interrelationship between dance, space and theater
- Comprehend the social meanings embedded in choreography, aesthetic valuing in dance and theater arts.
- Learn folk dance movement and be able to convey messages through body language.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 History of Dance : Ritual Dances
In most ancient civilizations, dancing before the god is an important element in temple rituals. The class proposes a transdisciplinary perspective to examine dance evolution based on performance theory and on myth.

Case study:
- Ancient Egyptian
- Greek Shrine
- Game as Olympia
- Dionysiac dances
- Fire dances

Readings: Dancing Greek Antiquity in Private and Public: Isadora Duncan's Early Patronage in Paris by Samuel N. Dorf, Dance Research Journal Volume 44, Number 1, 2012

Week 2 Evolution of Dance : From royal palace to folk dance
Functions of Dances and evolution of dance forms
Dance as entertainment, dance as display

Case study: Chinese dance from Han dynasty to contemporary dance
- Lion/Dragon Dance
- Feather Fan Dance
- Traditional Chinese Ribbon Dance
- Silk Fan Dance

Screenings and discussions: 扇舞民族舞
Chinese Literature and folk dances古典文學與現代民族舞
Peacock dances

Readings
The History of Chinese Dance, Ch 4. Kefen Wang, Foreign Languages Press, 1985

Week 3 Primitive Dances and Islandish Culture - Tahitian and Hula
The class explores the ancient origins of hula and the ties between Hawaiians of generations past and present
Hula - Once performed only by men in ancient Hawaii, the dance form in both ancient (kahiko) and contemporary ('auana) form is performed by both genders

Screenings and discussions:
- Dance and gender representations
- friendship and body language
- to examine the relationship between the nature, harmony and dance

Readings: Kumu hula: roots and braches book, chapter 2 & 3, Dr. Ishmael W. Stagner

Week 4 Ballet in Renaissance Italy and France: 15th - 17th century

A popular entertainment in Renaissance France and Italy
- performance dance that originated in the Italian Renaissance courts of the 15th century
- later developed into a concert dance form in France and Russia
- Its influences in classical folk dances around the world

Case study: Giselle by Coralli and Perot
Nutcracker by Petipa and Ivanov
Russian ballet, French ballet, Italian ballet and contemporary ballet.

Week 5 Dancing fear and desire: Middle Eastern Dance
Case study:　Raqs sharqi
Through historical investigation, theoretical analysis, and personal reflection, explores how Middle Eastern dance actively engages race, gender, sexuality, and national identity.

Screenings and discussions:
- Dance inspired by royal symbol of cobra
- dances under social reform
- From Middle Eastern to American Tribal dance fusion
- Issues: misconception of folk dances and prejudice of female dancers

Readings (paper): Bellydance: A Guide to Middle Eastern Dance, Its Music, Its Culture and Costume

Week 6 Tribal Culture and Dances
Case study: Afrian dance
Afrian tribal dances can be viewed in close connection with Sub-Saharan African music traditions and Bantu cultivation of rhythm.

- Tribal costumes and meanings
- Warrior Dances
- Dances of Welcome
- Dances of Possession and Summoning

African dance: an artistic, historical, and philosophical inquiry, Kariamu Welsh-Asante, Africa World Press, 1996
Week 7 Dance and theater in early modern Spain
Case study: Dance and Visual Culture since 19th century to contemporary Spain
- History and evolution of Flamenco, Sevillanas, Tango
Screening: Maria Pages production, Community dance rituals
Reading: Flamenco: The Dance of Spain's Andalusia by Bob Martin (Ch. 3)
Week 8 From Sanskrit to Bollywood
Case study: Indian Culture and Dance
- Classical Odyssey, Angikabhinaya dance, drama and gestures
The classical dance form performed usually describes a story between the good and the evil.

screenings and discussions
- Semiotics of Eye movement and facial expression
- Temple dance styles: Agamas are Bharata Natyam Odissi
- the evolution from ritual to modern fusion Bollywood
- Bollywood film industry and dance movies

Reading: Theory and Practice of Angikabhinaya (In Bharata Natyam) by Dr. Sandhya Purecha Hardcover (Edition: 2003) Bharatiya Vidya Bhavan.

Week 9 Workshop: Dance practices/or field trip (to be decided)
- Convey meanings, narratives and expressing emotions via dance movement
- Learning basic gestures and steps
- Art appreciation of folk dances
- Visiting theaters: understand performing arts, story telling and stage set-ups
- Q & A

Week 10 Modern Dance
Modern dance and theater since early 20th century
Introduction of Modern and postmodern dances and world renowned choreographers
- Radical dance, contemporary dance
- Analysis of German Choreographer Pina Bausch
- Martha Graham
- Bella Lewitzky
- Alvin Ailey

Week 11 Street Dance and Jazz Culture
Street dance is regarded improvisationl and social in nature, encouraging interaction and contact with spectators and other dancers.
Study of African American vernacular dance of the late 19th century to mid-20th century which influenced Jazz style

Case Study -Poping
- Jazz dance
- Hip Hop
- Free styles
- Break dance ( Moon Walk by Jackson in 80s)
- Tap dance –Gene Kelly (Dancing in the Rain)
- House dance

Readings: Jazz Dance: The Story of American Vernacular Dance- Marshall Winslow Stearns, Jean Stearns, Perseus Books Group, 1968

Week 12 Experimental dance and theater
Examine interrelations between technology, theatrical design and dances

Case Study: La MaMa theater, BAM, Broadway Musical and dance
- New media art and experimental theater
- Free style dances and off Broadway theaters in New York
Readings: Enchanted Evenings: The Broadway Musical from 'Show Boat' to Sondheim and Lloyd Webber (Geoffrey Block,Oxford Press, 2 Oct, 2009
Week 13 Final presentation
Presentation based on analytical papers
12-15 mins for Each group

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Modernity and Urban Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2042 is double-coded with CURE2016.)   This course is an introduction to the formation of modernity in relation to various aspects of urban culture. Tracing the development of cities and the urban cultures evolved within the new urban development since the 19th Century, cities such as Paris, London, New York will serve as 'texts' for analysis. Architecture, urban planning, artistic and intellectual movements as well as modes of everyday life in urban living are studied to demonstrate how the modern ways of thinking, seeing and living come into being. The course will also focus on the specificity of Hong Kong's experience in urban development and its adaptation of 'modernity' during a process of urbanization. The course will employ a wide range of visual images and audio-visual materials to explain the dynamism between modernity and urban culture.

To provide strategies to articulate cultural theories with our practices of everyday life

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Living in the Anthropocene: Nature, Culture and Power
courses.description: (UGEC2243 is double-coded with CURE2018.)  Human have altered the environment in ways that have no precedence in human history. Ecological crisis, environmental degradation, and extreme weathers have become the watchwords of contemporary politics. The conventional boundaries between “nature” and “culture” are now being questioned. How do nature, culture and power intersect in our everyday life? How do we get to understand issues of sustainability and environmental crisis from a broad historical perspective and global activism angle? How are gender, class and race interact with technology, damaged environment, animal and plant species? This course explores these questions and the rich debates in the emerging field of environmental humanity and literature of the Anthropocene.Class topics are organized on major global green movements that resisted oil pollution, toxic factories, logging companies, dam constructions and nuclear plant building. Students get to learn the historical developments of major environmental activism in the West and the global south. How was the Greenpeace founded? What is the Narmada Dam Movement in India? Do you know Ken Saro-Wiwa, an environmental activist against Shell oil pollution in Nigeria? In each class we examine historical texts, visual materials and theoretical debates to explore how environmental justice has been intertwined with histories of colonialism, neoliberalism, and questions of gender, race, poverty and class. Together the class explores the problem of the Anthropocene (Nature) in the context of colonial history, grass root struggles (Culture) and corporation greed (Power).This course addresses many of the 17 United Nation Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs): Climate Actions (13), Life on Land (15), Life below Water (14), Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions (16), Clean Energy (7), Reduced Inequalities (10), and Gender Inequality (5). Students are able to identify the weekly course content aligned with specific SDGs and be able to understand these goals in both historical and contemporary contexts.
