courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Power, Identity, and Inequality in Medicine
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the medical humanities, an interdisciplinary field of study that seeks to understand the social context of health and illness beyond the hospital, clinic, and laboratory. In particular, this course will emphasize the historical and cultural shaping of health disparities and examine how issues of power contribute to unequal patterns of risk and disease in our modern society. To do this, students will learn major theories and methods in the cultural study of health and medicine to understand how culture, power, and identity—including race, gender, capitalism, and colonialism— shapes the management of disease and individual illness experience in both Asian and global contexts. A critical concern in this course is how the organization of medical care confronts questions of social justice in medical treatment and public health in historical and contemporary contexts. Students will also grapple with the question of whether our institutions of medicine and public health function as a form of social control. By introducing students to the social components of health and illness, it aims to foster cross-disciplinary conversations across the faculties of arts, medicine, and other divisions at CUHK.Following the United Nations’ Sustainable Development Goal of Reducing Inequality (SDG #10), a central question in this course is how medical treatments, research, and public health confront, or fail to confront, issues of social justice in global contexts. Students will learn theoretical approaches to health and inequality to investigate how history, culture, and politics shape the illness experience of socially marginalized people. These theories will enable students to assess the strengths and limits of our current arrangements of medical care and approaches to global health. In addition, students will learn critical medical humanities methods, such as ethnography, and use these methods to propose solutions to our current shortcomings in health governance. This course will challenge students to imagine better alternatives to our unequal world and demonstrate why the study of culture matters in medicine, global health, and public policy.
courses.learning_outcomes:
- Analyze how social inequality shapes disease outcomes (SDG #10)

- Explain how media shapes public understandings of health and disease, including stigma

- Situate individual illness experience in the social, political, and cultural contexts of disease

- Implement the use of ethnography to develop health policies that can reduce inequality (SDG #10)
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Introduction: Critical Medical Humanities**

In this introductory class, students will learn about the critical medical humanities as a method for interrogating fundamental questions of social justice in medicine: who gets sick, who gets better, and why? Students will be introduced to basic theories and concepts in the cultural studies of health and disease, such as stigma, biopolitics, and illness discourse, as tools for analyzing the complex social forces that shape health disparities. In addition, students will be provided with a basic introduction to public health systems, as well as information about the places and time periods that will be covered in the course.

* *Unit One: Race and Disease**

This unit starts with the histories of international disease control in Asian contexts, with emphasis on how social, cultural, and racial differences shaped the management of disease in colonial spaces. Students will analyze how issues of power and identity inform public health interventions, which often protects the privileged while stigmatizing and harming others. We will use the Hong Kong plague outbreak of 1894 as a case study in health inequity and learn, for example, about the homes of migrant Chinese labourers being burned by colonial officials in the name of disease control. We will conclude the unit by reflecting on how ideas of race and other forms social difference still shape the framing of disease even in contemporary discourses. Students will utilize cultural theories on race, gender, class, and inequality to identify how social biases shapes disease perception and response to reduce health inequality.

* *1. Difference and Disease in Tropical Medicine**

Key themes: hygienic modernity, power/knowledge, the “native” body, the laboratory in colonial discourse, vaccine politics

* *2. Colonial Tensions in Hong Kong’s Plague Pandemic**

Key themes: race and space, epidemic orientalism, the politics of quarantine and sanitary regimes, germ theory vs. local knowledge

* *3. Representing Disease**

Key themes: cultural representations of “the other” in disease discourse, endemicity as a cultural concept, body politics, the role of media in shaping disease response, global health

* *Unit Two: The Politics of Identity in Medicine**

Why are doctors often men? Why do doctors often come from socially dominant groups in terms of ethnicity and class privilege? What are the implications for how medicine is practiced? This unit offers answers to some of these questions by exploring the power structures that shape our institutions of medicine. We start with examining the social power of physicians. Students will learn about the social factors that shape how medical conditions come to be recognized, and the populations that are excluded or harmed in the pursuit of medical advancement. By understanding the politics of identity in medicine, students will gain the conceptual tools for understanding the health disparities that result when medicine often reflects the interests of socially dominant groups. Course discussions will invite students to apply concepts learned in this unit to address health disparities here in Hong Kong, where ethnic minorities representing 8.4% of the population face barriers in accessing care, mental health resources are not yet able to address demand, and a fragile public health system offers diminished care for the city’s neediest.

* *4. Physician Power**

Key themes: medicalization, normal vs. pathological, social control, illness narrative

* *5. Medical Experimentation**

Key themes: medical mistrust, medical gaze, ethical variation, biopolitics, bare life

* *6. Gender and Medicine I**

Key themes: gender discrimination in medicine, bias in clinical research, androcentrism, experiential knowledge, situated knowledge

* *7. Gender and Medicine II**

Key themes: patient activism, advocacy, biosociality, online communities

* *Unit Three: Medicine, Power, and Structural Violence**

In this final unit, we will connect individual illness experiences to the broader social, economic, and structural factors that result in ill health, such as poverty, uneven development, forced migration, and others. This unit will emphasize the illness experiences of marginalized social groups to examine the effects of social, political, and economic disenfranchisement on their bodies and health. By examining health and illness at the level of everyday life, students will develop an understanding of how ethnographic methods can be used to make interventions in health policy. In the concluding week, we will wrap up with a discussion about who benefits, and who may be harmed, in our current global health system and propose ways to align global health priorities with the principles health justice.

* *8. Structural Violence and Health Disparities**

Key themes: structural violence, embodiment, subjectivity, illness narrative, decolonization

* *9. Health and Human Rights**

Key themes: health justice, migrant health, human rights, social safety nets, undocumented

* *10. Neoliberal Logics in Global Health**

Key themes: biomedicalization, clinical trials, commodification of health, globalization

* *11. Conclusion: Inequality in Global Health Systems**

courses.title: Feminisms: Thoughts and Movements
courses.description: (UGEC2273 is double-coded with CURE2022.)  A long-lasting struggle of gender equity was triggered by the women’s movements in England and U.S in the end of 19th century. Feminists fight for equality by publications, demonstrations and organizations. In 20th century, the feminist movement matured. Feminists have been more sensitive to the differences among women of different race, class, culture, religion and circumstances and noticed the importance of differences in unity. This course will introduce the strategies and main arguments of various kinds of feminism. Through learning from others’ experience, history and our daily life, we will understand the development of diversity in feminisms. We can have more understanding of feminists fighting for the right of disadvantage groups by self-review and mutual criticism in different times and culture.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Taiwan New Cinema and Beyond: Authorship, Transnationality, Historiography
courses.description: This course aims to familiarise students with the key works of the Taiwan New Cinema movement and its legacy beyond Taiwan and into the twenty-first century. It will explore not just the work of a wide array of film directors, but also the texts and the condition of their production, distribution, exhibition and consumption within a transnational framework, all of which impinge on the question of “national” film historiography. It will examine, in particular: the socio-political background of the emergence of the Taiwan New Cinema movement, its key directors and their works, the international context of their reception and the transnational nature of their production, and its legacy to date. It will provide students with an in-depth knowledge of the work of selected film authors and an awareness of the cinematic, cultural, and socio-political contexts in which they work, and enable students to analyse the work in relation to questions of transnationality and historiography.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of this module, you should be able to:

Module-specific skills:

a.Demonstrate an advanced appreciation of the historical development of the Taiwan New Cinema movement, and its key directors and films.

b.Demonstrate an informed appreciation of how concepts of film authorship can be related to modes of production, modes of funding, and an international context of cinephilia.

c.Demonstrate an advanced critical understanding of key debates on the various aspects of transnational cinemas, from production and distribution to the analysis of texts and authors.

d.Demonstrate an advanced critical capacity to interrogate the notion of “national cinema” and the way in which it has been challenged in film historiography.

Discipline-specific skills:

a.Demonstrate an advanced capacity to analyse films from different periods in the Taiwan New Cinema movement and to relate their concerns and modes of expression to their historical contexts.

b.Demonstrate advanced analytical skills in the close formal, thematic, generic and authorial analysis of different kinds of films.

c.Demonstrate advanced intellectual and critical skills in the research and evaluation of relevant material for the study of film and communicate these conclusions effectively and fluently using appropriate critical and technical language.

d.Demonstrate an advanced capacity to consider the relationship between film and its complex production conditions and to relate film history to a wider context beyond the national.

Personal and key skills:

a.Undertake independent research on the basis of a taught course.

b.Adopt a critical approach to the selection and organisation of a large body of material in order to produce, to a deadline, a written, oral or visually sustained argument of some complexity.

c.Present a cogent and sustained argument orally / in writing, in English, on an aspect of the subject of the student’s own choosing, and selecting appropriate methods of exposition.

d.Using bibliographical material provided, select, plan and carry out a programme of study leading to an essay / presentation on a chosen topic, to a specified length and deadline.

e.Demonstrate ability to combine a variety of IT skills in researching and reporting on a topic.

Week 1 Taiwan Cinema Before “Taiwan New Cinema”

Week 10 Transnationality (III): Southeast Asia

Week 11 Historiography (I): Sinophone Cinema

Week 13 Essay writing workshop and consultation

Week 14 Essay writing workshop and consultation

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Contemporary Consumer Culture
courses.description: This course surveys a wide range of topics on the commercialization of sports, tourism/leisure as an encounter of cultures/citizens/space, shopping mall and public sphere, and the impact on social and cultural life by the phenomenon of McDisneyization. Other topics such as advertising and pop culture, broadcasting (narrowcasting on the Net), merchandising and iconography in fashion will be examined to review key contemporary issues and debates about cultural consumption. Bringing together work on reception theory in literary studies and philosophy, studies on consumer culture in anthropology and sociology and those on media audiences within media studies, we will address the consequences and effects of increasing cultural commodifiaction and globalization, by exploring into the complex interactions of cultural production and consumption which are relevant in topics such as place and identity, visual culture and hyperreality, representation and communication technologies. Films and animations will be viewed outside class time. Field trips may be arranged.
courses.learning_outcomes:
With this course we embark on a self-investigative journey into our dominant way of life—consumption. Here we are going to de-familiarize consumer society and our daily consumption practices, in order to learn how patterns of consumption work, and to consider consequences of such culture.

We approach the topics with a number of theoretical perspectives, arguments, and illustrations. Students are expected to look into these everyday occurrences with sociological, anthropological, literary, and philosophical analytical tools. This course may help us reflect not only on our relationship with commodity in general, but also our increasingly mediated connection to the world, our community, and even to ourselves. The mediation as such is not so much in the traditional, materialistic sense of use and pleasurable experience, as melting of all that is solid into signs and their consumption. Emphasis will be placed on developing students’ analytical as well as cultural critical skills, or in other words, ability to un-learn the born-again consumer.

1) Knowledge Outcomes
Theories and perspectives of contemporary consumption culture
Characteristics of consumer culture and their global nature
Consequences and ethical appropriation of consumerism

2) Skill Outcomes
Articulating theories and practices in understanding phenomena of consumption
Creative project making to address to some of the obvious problems in consumerism

3) Attitude Outcomes
Balance between critical and pedagogical approach
Creative learning and un-learning through everyday life experiences

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Photographic Culture and Visual Communication
courses.description: Photographs have tremendous power to communicate information; on the other hand, encoding and decoding metaphors of photographs present a unique set of challenges. This course can help students interpret and understand photographs meaningfully, later they can learn how to convey messages creatively. This course combines both the theoretical and hands-on approach to allow students to explore their creative visual expression and to learn the technical applications of the photographic medium such as camera basics, lighting and digital applications. It discusses the fundamentals of photography from the historical, cultural, aesthetical and technological perspectives. In particular, this course will cover aesthetical theories, social reflections, various genres of photography. To ensure that students be successful in their own personal and educational goals, they will be asked to create a digital portfolio on the Internet, as well as making selected photographic assignments of presentable quality.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Analytical Ability: Learn to think critically about the surrounding world of
imagery, to show a deeper understanding of the way aesthetic knowledge and value judgments impact photographic art. Uses case studies to explain photographic practices in contemporary art and place them in the context of theory

2. Creative Explorations: to broaden the student’s horizon by making them knowledgeable about most influential photographs that changed the world; Develop and enhance his/her proficiency in the vocabulary of the photographers. Above allows students to develop an individualized creative style and gain informed insights.
3. Technological skills: Learn to convey messages through the lens, understand the primary controls of a camera, and develop problem-solving skills; to acquire a general understanding of digital imaging applications.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Hong Kong Cinema
courses.description: (UGEC2241 is double-coded with CURE2030.)  This course is a survey of Hong Kong cinema, with emphasis on its contemporary development. This course will cover both textual and contextual analyses: we treat Hong Kong cinema as an art form and introduce different ways to appreciate them and criticize them; we also read these films as commercial cultural products to investigate links between movies and society at-large. The course will introduce basic film theories and film languages. It helps students to reflect on their own relationship with these Hong Kong movies they grow up with, as well as help elucidate the complex relationship between Hong Kong cinema and Hong Kong identity.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
CURE2030 is double-coded with UGEC2241.
Not for students who have taken UGEC2241 or 2774.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to acquire a general understanding of basic film languages, and to develop basic skill in film appreciation and film criticism. After the course students should be able to understand Hong Kong history and Hong Kong society from the perspective of cinema, with critical awareness of related issues pertaining to gender, class, and cultural identity. They are also expected to understand the intimate relationship between film production and film consumption, as well as the differences and connections between art and commerce in the domain of Hong Kong cinema.
courses.course_syllabus:
The lectures are organized historically, allowing students to gain a full picture of not only Hong Kong cinema’s history but also the history of Hong Kong. Students will also learn the basic techniques of film appreciation and film criticism through the various examples introduced. Lectures are composed of lecturer’s presentation and close analysis of selected film clips, through which students will be called attentions to specific stylistic, thematic, and theoretical issues. Combining the lectures and film analysis, students will learn both specific issues about Hong Kong cinema and acquire basic training of film analysis.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Understanding Visual Culture
courses.description: This course introduces students how to understand and be critical of visual culture. We will study carefully and critically various forms of representations to the issues of paintings, illustrations, photography, films, television, and video games. We will learn the languages developed for these visual forms, and how ideologies are structured and conveyed through these visual depictions. In this visual age, while we are bombarded with more and more visual information and sensations, we are also effectively deskilled in our capacities as interpretive beings in critically engaging with these visual representations. This course teaches students how to appreciate the rich hermeneutic possibilities inherent in the visual culture and at the same time to be critical of ways that the viewers are rendered vulnerable to be manipulated by the visual images.
courses.learning_outcomes: Students in this course are expected to learn how our social order and communities are made up of visual languages and expressions. They are also expected to know the ideological and economic links among production, circulation, and consumption in the realm of visual culture. Through an interdisciplinary approach, students would develop a visual literacy, learning that meanings and emotions can be conveyed visually. Students will also develop critical awareness related to issues pertaining to gender, racial, class, and national identities through the studies of visual representations.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Youth and Popular Culture
courses.description: This course studies the relationship between youth and popular culture, specifically in view of the rapidly expanding youth culture in recent years. We explore the importance of the factor of age in the study of popular culture, explaining why youths are vulnerable to the manipulation of popular culture, and why their lifestyles and values also dominate popular culture. We also examine how youth identity is constructed around the dynamics between mainstream identity and subcultural identity, and students are given the chance to analyse their own socio-cultural worlds in the various cultural environment, including home, school, concerts, shopping malls, youth magazines, and the cyber-space. This course provides students with an understanding of why youths, in particular, are prone to collective identity, and how they achieve their sense of self through fashion, music, sports, and entertainment.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Queer Theory and Culture
courses.description: Queer Theories emerged in the 1990s as some of the most vital analytical tools in the fields of Gender Studies and Cultural Studies. This course offers students an opportunity to study this strand of critical thought in-depth. It will examine theories of queer from four major approaches, namely: historical, political, reading and performative. Topics of the course will cover a wide range of subjects including identities, sexualities, temporalities, homophobia, activism, deviance, and transgression. This course is particularly suited for students who would like to acquire the knowledge of a particular theoretical approach and to engage it in a critical examination of literature and culture today.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Cultural Policy
courses.description: This course will introduce students to the historical and contemporary debate in Hong Kong and around the world on what constitutes culture and how governments and other organizations can help sustain cultural development. Particular emphasis will be placed on the context of Hong Kong and other cosmopolitan cities to examine how cultural policy can help shape a pluralist society. We will also discuss the challenges and distortion posed by economic and management criteria practised in today's capitalist societies to the intrinsic value of culture and the arts.
courses.learning_outcomes: In terms of knowledge acquisition, students are expected to understand how policies on culture is shaped and their impacts on the development of society in terms of the make-up of our regional, national and global orders; their role in the shaping of cultural practices, expressions and ideology; their relations to production and enterprising and hence their role in the shaping of our identity, taste and values as well as economy and policies. In terms of values and skills, students are expected to develop critical ability in analyzing the diversity of values and interests, inter-cultural sensitivity, a balance view of local and global issues, literacy in understanding different visual and textual meanings and forms and the ability to appreciate the importance and significance of the inter-disciplinary nature of cultural policies.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Trans-Asian Bodies and Visual Fantasy Cultures
courses.description: This course analyses how Asian bodies and identities are represented in media and visual fantasy cultures such as Japanese animation, social networks, and performative subcultures. We explore how the extreme cultural and social diversity of the Asian region contributes to unique perspectives on bodies and identities. We are particularly interested in the studies of trans-Asian cultural flows, which includes not only commodities and entertainments but also migrations, like workers, and specific thoughts, like Maoism or human rights. We believe that a careful reading of these transnational flows would help us reconsider what Hong Kong culture and Chinese culture mean in contemporary bodies and indentity. We compare the cultural studies of local cultures with the discourses of trans-Asian studies and globalization, with the aim to demonstrate the possible ideological traps and strengths of taking Asia as an academic category for studying the body and culture.
courses.learning_outcomes:
On successful completion of the course, you will be able to:

1. Understand the diversity and similarities of different Asian cultures and subcultures in constructing the body
2. Understand the unique position of Asia in current discourse on the body and identity.
3. Able to critically apply or interrogate Western based theories with specific Asian case studies
4. Able to understand the relationship between cultural representations and social conditions of the body
5. Gain a unique understanding of Hong Kong and China from the perspective of Asia

學習成果：

當你成功修畢本課程之後將會：
1瞭解不同的亞洲文化和次文化在建構身體上的多元性和相似性。
2瞭解亞洲在當代身體和身分論述中的獨特位置。
3能夠批判性地運用或整合西方理論與特定的亞洲案例研究。

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Television Studies
courses.description: This course aims to introduce the major studies of television understood as a set of institutions, technologies and texts shaped by historical, cultural, political and economic forces. This course examines television’s historical evolution; its relationship to other media; its preferred genres; its models of televisual spectatorship and consumption; its politics of representation in regard to class, race, gender, and sexuality; and its economic modes of operation. Upon completion of this subject, students are expected to understand the content and form of television as well as its industrial, social, cultural, and technological ramifications.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Identify and analyze important concepts in television studies
2. Analyze and interpret television as a form of creative expression with regard to its multiple genres, means of delivery, and formal methods
3. Evaluate relevant aspects of television that not only reflect on society but also shape values and meanings
4. Articulate their understanding of television as a complex medium with industrial, social, cultural, and technological ramifications.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Xiqu and Culture
courses.description: (UGEC2294 is double-coded with CURE2042.)  The course introduces the student a basic knowledge of Xiqu (Chinese Opera), including its artistic features as a performing art, and the characteristics of different kinds of local Xiqu, such as Beijing Opera, Kunqu, Shanghai Opera and Cantonese Opera. Based on the basic knowledge of the art-form, we will discuss the cultural issues reflecting in the plays and performances. Through the textual analysis of scripts and performances, students will be introduced different topics of Xiqu related to cultural studies.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Performance Studies
courses.description: Performances are actions, and "Performance Studies" is defined as interdisciplinary studies of human actions ranging from ritual, theatre, dance, music, popular entertainments as well as everyday life practice. The aim of this course is to provide the students with a knowledge of and insight into the key concepts, the historical development, and the socio-cultural implications of performance both in international scene and local context. Not only do we study the archives, the manifestations, the theory and the practice of various performers, composers, choreographers, actors, art and stage directors from different periods and traditions, but we also focus on the interpretation and communication, the audience reception and spectatorship of the social mass. It is a course draws on a wide variety of disciplines including social sciences, semiotics, speech-act theory, psychoanalysis, gender and queer studies, with which we can investigate the stylistic features, the quality of theatricality, the technical change, the hybridity and the boundary-crossing of performance in our era.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Understanding Comic Arts
courses.description: (UGED2326 is double-coded with CURE2051.)   Nowadays comic strip has become one of the major forms of visual narratives in our culture. Both comics and film are visual arts originally developed within the period of late 19th century and early 20th century. Although film has long ago established its artistic legitimacy, comic art still struggle for recognition. However, as Will Eisner put it, comic strip is a “Sequential Art” and has its own unique aesthetic nature. This course tries to inquire the governing aesthetic principles of comics and investigate its unique method of expression. We will also try to delineate the special communication mode of comics and its relationship with different aspects of modern society and culture. Students will learn to appreciate comic art from different perspectives, and strengthen analytical skills for visual media.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Through the lectures, students will recognize the aesthetic nature of sequential art and locate the humanistic values and meanings of comic arts for modern society and culture.

2. Through tutorial discussions, student will apply the analytical skills and formal methods to interpret comic and visual texts.

3. Through mid-term assignment (research portfolio on the visual representation of comics), student will distinguish, compare, analyze and criticize different visual and multimedia sources.

4. Through final paper, student will prepare and manage to do an academic research on visual representation.

5. Student will aware, judge and appraise the practical values of the analytical skills and historical knowledge provided by this course after they complete the mid-term assignment and final paper.

courses.subject: CURE

courses.description: This practical class consists of lectures, readings, hands-on visual projects, and workshops, in which two main software will be taught: Adobe Photoshop and Adobe Premiere. Students will examine visual experiences from the perspectives of creators and viewers and will learn how to design images, edit videos, and add primary visual effects for their projects. At the same time, the practical work with these tools will help us better understand how they are used in society - the modes of thinking and inquiry they enable, their strengths and weaknesses.
courses.learning_outcomes:

- Apply essential skills and concepts in the development of critical and innovative design outcomes.

- Students will gain experiences from technologies and methods related to visual cultures

and aesthetic functions in learning design.

- Develop students’ aesthetic sensitivity and the ability of visual aesthetic judgment. - Enhance students’ portfolio for job seeking.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Myth, Symbol and Ritual
courses.description: This course deals with the inter-relationship of myth, symbol and ritual, which are believed to play important part in human religious configuration. The human meaning of myth, symbol and ritual will be recovered in the context of social, cultural and psychological effects upon their believers. Meanwhile, theories and historical examples will be emphasized.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge outcomes
Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to understand:
(1) the role of myth, symbol and ritual in the human religious configuration;
(2) the various theoretical approaches to the study of religions and their social, cultural and psychological effects upon their believers; and
(3) the way religious symbol, myth and ritual interact with society: how they operate within, and are produced by society.

Attitude outcomes
Upon successful completion of the course, students are expected:
(1) to understand how myth, symbol, and ritual operate, consciously or unconsciously, in our daily life;
(2) to develop a critical approach to examine the various components embodied in religious faiths;
(3) to be able to cross disciplinary boundaries with an analytical mind; and
(4) to be able to integrate theory and practice.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Sociology of Religion
courses.description: An introduction to the scientific study of the social aspects of religion from the sociological point of view. This includes an exploration of the interaction between religion and culture; a survey of religion as a social institution; and an examination of the relationship between religion and other major social institutions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge outcomes
1. To understand the sociological major definitions of religion
2. To understand the major methodologies and key issues of the sociological study of religion
3. To be able to analyze religious phenomena by using the sociological approach

Attitude outcomes
1. To develop a critical yet constructive attitude in understanding religious phenomena.
2. To develop a sensitivity to religious phenomena in modern societies.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Course Introduction : Syllabus
2) (Instructor out of Hong Kong)
3) Defining religion sociologically : Characteristics of the sociology of religion; sociological assumptions; sociological definition of religion
4) Religion and meaning : Meaning and sacredness, conversion and commitment, religious experience
5) Secularization and Resacralization : Secularization theory and its criticisms, civil religion, invisible religion
6) Rational choice theory : Rational Choice theory and its criticisms
7) Religious organizations, institutions and authority : Church-sect typology; new religious movements
8) Religion and social change : Religion supporting the status quo, religion promotes social change
9) Religion and social differentiation : Issues of social class, gender, sexual identity, and religion
10) Project presentations (1)
11) Project presentations (2)
12) Project presentations (3)
13) The Future of religion

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Psychology of Religion
courses.description: An examination of various aspects of religion from a psychological perspective. The contribution of such men as W. James, C. Jung and A. Maslow will be considered.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of the course, students are able to:
1) demonstrate familiarity with the conceptual debates and controversies within the psychological study of religion.
2) identify key concepts in psychological studies of religious experiences and beliefs.
3) discuss how religion informs an individual's worldview and social behaviors.
4) apply important concepts, theories, and research findings from the course to study religious phenomena.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Overview of the Field of Religion and Psychology
1) Introduction: Overview of the field of religion and psychology
2) Psychology of Religion: Classics and Contemporary (I)
3) Psychology of Religion: Classics and Contemporary (II)

Part II: Religion as a Meaning System in a Personal’s Live
4) Religion and Personality
What kind of person would believe in God? Religious Orientations
5) Religion as a Call for Change: Cognitive and Affective Effects (I)
Conversion, Varieties of Religion Experiences, and Mystical Experiences
6) Religion as a Call for Change: Cognitive and Affective Effects (II)
Religiosity, Values, and Goal-Regulation; Christian, Taoist and Buddhist experiences
7) Field Trip (to be confirmed)
8) Religion, Death and Harming
Fear of death and social behaviour; cults, violence, and religious terrorism
9) Religion and Well-Beings
Coping, Adjustment Process, and Mental Health

Part III: Religion, Social Psychology and Society
10) Psychosocial Differences across Religions:
Religious Orientations, Religious Values and Social Behaviors
11) Religion as a Factor of Conflicts and Resolutions
Social Class, In-group Bias, Prejudice, Helping and Parenting the spiritual realm
12) Religion and Forgiveness
13) The Future of the Psychology of Religion (Conclusion) - Guest lecture on spirituality, healing and empowerment
14) Reflection; Paper Submission

courses.description: The aim of this course is to explore the historical development of Taoism as a religion in Hong Kong. It will examine the historical link between Hong Kong Taoism and Taoism in traditional China, and will show how the activities of Hong Kong Taoism reflect the local religious characteristics of Hong Kong people.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Christianity and Western Literature
courses.description: The purpose of this course is to expose students to the interactive relationship between Christianity and Western Literature. It may include literary works such as Augustine’s Confessions, Boethius’ Consolation of Philosophy, Abelard’s History of Calamities, Dante's Commedia, Shakespeare’s King Lear, Milton's Paradise Lost, Goethe’s Faust, Tolstoy’s The Kingdom of God is Within You, Dostoevsky’s The Brothers Karamazov, etc.; and focuses on the themes of creation, sin, fall, suffering, love, spirituality, redemption, purgatory, forgiveness, pride, peace, Kingdom of God, Nature, etc.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Knowledge: Students will gain basic understandings of the relationship between Christianity and Western Literature.

2) Skill: Students will learn the skills of interpreting literature from both literary and religious perspectives

3) Attitude: Students will acquire the attitude to respective different interpretations regarding literature as well as religion.

1. Introduction: Relationship between Christianity and Western Literature
2. Augustine, *Confessions*, creation and sin
3. Boethius, *Consolation of Philosophy*, and suffering
4. Abelard, *History of Calamities*, and Love
5. Thomas á Kempis, *Imitation of Christ*, and Spirituality
6. Dante, *Commedia*, and purgatory
7. Shakespeare, *King Lear*, and forgiveness
8. Milton, *Paradise Lost*, and fall
9. Goethe, *Faust*, and pride
10. Tolstoy, *The Kingdom of God is Within You,* and non-violence
11. Dostoevsky’s *The Brothers Karamazov*, and redemption
12. Emerson, *Nature*, and environment
13. Contemporary variations of the interactive relationship

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduct'n to Taoist Literature
courses.description: The aim of this course is to introduce students to the Taoist literature in Chinese history. While there are many approaches to the understanding of the discipline of religion and literature, this course covers traditional Chinese literature in relation to Taoist thought, practice, institution, and symbolism. The focus is on the formation of literary genres as religious expression and transcendental imagination in the context, as much as possible, of the development of Taoist religion. This will allow us not only to realize literature as the principal record of Taoist tradition in its confirmation and valorization of Taoist values, but also to grapple with the literary challenge to inherited orthodoxies and thus the undermining of conventional ideas and feelings, as well as to sample the texture of literature functioning as an alternative or substitute for Taoism. In this way, we can approach the intersections of the aesthetic and the religious as the essential humanity through the reading and analysis of the Taoist dimensions of literature.
courses.learning_outcomes:
微觀：

1. 對中國歷史上的道教文學有基本的認識；
2. 明白中國傳統文學與道教教義、儀式、制度和象徵的關係；
3. 對歷代文學作家創作背後的道教宗教性語景有基本的認識；
4. 對道教表達信仰及想像的基本體裁；
5. 以宗教現象學的研究視野，通過文學明白道教的宇宙論、鬼神觀、身體觀、道德觀等基本概念在文學中的呈現；
6. 通過文學讓同學明白道教作為中國土生土長的宗教，在文化長河中的位置及影響力。

宏觀：

1. 學習從出土文物、藝術、文學及經典文獻等第一手了解宗教現象；
2. 掌握搜尋學術論文等第二手資料的能力；
3. 明白在了解一個宗教時，需要用不同的視野進行探索。

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Religion and Ethics
courses.description: An examination of the relationship of the Christian and various other world views to ethical issues of contemporary society.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part One: Approaches of Ethics

Lecture 1 : Virtue Ethics, Becoming a “Virtuous Being”

Lecture 2 : Natural Law Ethics, Conforming to the law of the “Natural”

Lecture 3 : Teleology, Utilitarianism, Achieving “What is Good”

Lecture 4 : Deontology, Kantian Ethics, The Divine Command Theory, Doing “What is Right”

Lecture 5 : Ethics of Responsibility, Responsive to Others’ Needs, Doing “What is Fitting”

Lecture 6 : Whether Ethics is dependent on Religion?

Part Two: Relationships between Religion and Ethics

Lecture 7 : Ethical Disaster Reshaping Religious Thought

Lecture 8 : Religious Resources for Ethics: Scripture, Tradition, Reason, Experience

Part Three: Facing Ethical Issues in Religious Perspectives

Lecture 9 : Technology

Lecture 10 : Just War

Lecture 11 : Economics

Lecture 12 : Ecology
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to give comments and feedback on the course through emails in Moodle or personal exchanges with instructor and/or tutors. An end-of-term university wide course evaluation will be conducted in class.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Life and Death in Religions
courses.description: Life and death are the central concerns in most religious traditions, which are usually transmitted through religious texts and rituals. Related themes include body, good life and good death, meaning of life, etc. This course will take a thematic approach to examine the issues related to life and death in major religions in the world, including the Chinese, Indian, and Abrahamic traditions. At the end of the course students should have gained a comprehensive understanding of the life-course models, the symbolism of death, the death rituals and the meaning of life in these major religious traditions.

Topic

1. Introduction: Cosmological Contexts and the Theory of the Soul

3. Death and Afterlife in the Old Testament

• Recommended Reading:

George E. Mendenhall, “From Witchcraft to Justice: Death and Afterlife in the Old Testament,” Death and After Life: Perspectives of World Religions.

4. Death and Eternal Life in Christianity

5. Death and afterlife in Chinese religions

• Recommended Reading:

Thomas J. Hopkins, “Hindu Views of Death and After Life.” (Chapter 10) In Death and After Life: Perspectives of World Religions.

8. Life and Death in Buddhist Thought

• Recommended Reading:

courses.title: New Religious Movements
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students tools and concepts with which to understand and study New Religious Movements (NRMs) and to promote religious tolerance. This course is divided into three parts: first of all, the significance and the methodological issues of New Religious Movements; secondly, some important issues on New Religious Movements, including rituals, gender, and economic dimension; third, Theoretical consideration and critique.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Foundational Medieval Latin
courses.description: This course provides a comprehensive introduction to Latin grammar and reading skills. Students will master fundamental structures including: noun declensions and cases, regular verb conjugations, adjective agreement, pronouns, and basic syntax. The course develops essential vocabulary and translation skills through carefully selected Latin readings of progressive difficulty.Through systematic study of grammar and syntax complemented by regular practice in translation, students will build the foundational competency needed for reading Latin texts. By the end of the course, students will be able to read adapted Latin passages, demonstrate command of basic grammatical structures, and be prepared for intermediate-level Latin study.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Master basic Latin pronunciation and demonstrate competency in reading aloud, with proper attention to syllable length and stress
2. Demonstrate competency in fundamental Latin grammar, including recognition and formation of basic noun and verb patterns, declensions, conjugations, and essential pronouns
3. Build and effectively use a basic Latin vocabulary focused on high-frequency words and common expressions, enabling comprehension of simple texts
4. Read, translate, and analyze adapted Latin texts with proper attention to basic grammatical structures, including cases, tenses, and word order
courses.course_syllabus:
Core Contents:

Pronunciation and Reading; Nouns and Cases; Regular Verb Conjugations; Present/Perfect/Imperfect Tenses; Adjectives and Agreement; Essential Pronouns; Basic Prepositions; Simple Sentence Structures

13-Week Course Outline:

Week 1: Introduction to Latin

• Latin alphabet and pronunciation

• Basic sentence structure

• Introduction to inflected language concept

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Introduction

Week 2: First Declension

• First declension nouns

• Nominative and accusative cases

• Present tense of esse (to be)

• Simple subject-predicate sentences

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 2; 拉丁語法入門§100

Week 3: Second Declension

• Second declension nouns

• Genitive case

• Gender in Latin

• Simple possessive constructions

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 3; 拉丁語法入門§100

Week 4: First Conjugation

• Present tense of regular -āre verbs

• Subject-verb agreement

• Direct objects

• Simple active sentences

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 1; 拉丁語法入門§900

Week 5: Adjectives

• First/second declension adjectives

• Agreement with nouns

• Predicate adjectives

• Descriptive phrases

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapters 2-4; 拉丁語法入門§300

Week 6: Second Conjugation

• Present tense of regular -ēre verbs

• Dative case introduction

• Indirect objects

• Simple questions

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 5; 拉丁語法入門§900

Week 7: Prepositions

• Common prepositions

• Ablative case introduction

• Prepositional phrases

• Place expressions

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 14; 拉丁語法入門§500

Week 8: Third Conjugation

• Present tense of regular -ere verbs

• Personal pronouns

• Basic word order

• Simple commands

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 1; 拉丁語法入門§930

Week 9: Fourth Conjugation

• Present tense of regular -īre verbs

• Demonstrative adjectives (hic, ille)

• Time expressions

• Simple dialogue

Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 10; 拉丁語法入門§940

Week 10: Pronouns

• Personal pronouns (ego, tu, nos, vos)

• Demonstrative pronouns (hic, ille)

• Interrogative pronouns (quis, quid)

• Basic relative pronoun (qui, quae, quod)

• Common expressions with pronouns

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 11 and 13; 拉丁語法入門§940

Week 11: Imperfect Tense

• Imperfect tense of regular verbs

• Past time expressions

• Continuing actions

• Simple stories

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 5; 拉丁語法入門§940

Week 12: Perfect Tense

• Perfect tense of regular verbs

• Common irregular perfects

• Completed actions

• Past narratives

• Textbook: Wheelock’s Latin, Chapter 12; 拉丁語法入門§940

Week 13: Review and Integration

• Comprehensive review

• Reading practice

• Translation skills

• Common Latin phrases

• Cultural backgroun

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Beginning Sanskrit
courses.description: Sanskrit is India's venerable and ancient language of learning, a key sustainer of 'high' culture and religion since at least 3000 years that continues today to be an important medium of religious, literary, and philosophical discourse. It is also of great importance in much Buddhist as well as Hindu texts, and factors importantly into several southeast Asian languages and cultures. This course will introduce the language, overviewing essential and intriguing features while providing basics in pronunciation, grammar, and vocabulary to appreciate its richness and expressiveness.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge and attitude outcomes
At the end of the course, a student should be able to demonstrate:
1. knowledge and understanding of Devanagari letters and sandhis.
2. knowledge and understanding of basic Sanskrit grammar and vocabulary.
3. knowledge and understanding of the basic Sanskrit structures and expressions.
4. the ability to understand simple narrative texts in written Sanskrit on topics of Indian religions.
5. the capability and awareness of utilizing a classical language in religious studies.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Religion, Health and Healing
courses.description: Religious traditions contain particular understandings of body and mind, health and wholeness, illness and suffering, healing and transformation. This course will cover the latest discussion on the relationship among religion, health and healing. Also, it will explore the health/healing beliefs and practices in different religious traditions such as Taoism, Judaism, Christianity, Muslim, and New Age Movement, as well as will contrast those beliefs and practices with the hegemony of secular western biomedicine. The central goal of the course will bring students to understand how religious health/healing practices are constructed and experienced as meaningful in today's rapidly changing and globalized world.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of the course, students are able to:
1) understand the ways that body and mind, health and wholeness, illness and suffering, healing and transformation are constructed in different religious traditions such as Taoism, Judaism, Christianity, Muslim, and New Age Movement.
2) understand the roles that religious practices can play in developing therapeutic understanding and facilitating effective healing process.
3) critically compare the health/healing beliefs and practices in religious traditions and in western biomedicine systems.
4) understand the importance of a holistic approach to health and healing.

1. Introduction to Religion, Health, and Healing
2. Secular Biomedicine and its Impact on Health
3. Taoist Healing Arts and Transformation
4. Health and Healing in Buddhist Tradition
5. Health and Healing in Jewish Tradition
6. Christianity and Health Practices
7. Muslim Perspectives on Health and Healing
8. New Age Movement and Alternative Healing
9. Religion and Mental Health: Beliefs, Stigma, and Treatment
10. Sacred Spaces and Healing Environments
11. Contemporary Issues in Religion, Health, and Healing
12. Global Perspectives on Religion, Health, and Healing

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduction to Buddhism
courses.description: Buddhism has demonstrated a visible ability to adapt to changing cultures and regions for over 2,500 years. This course provides students with a general introduction to Buddhism. In this course, participants will investigate various thematic and specific aspects concerning the long and complex histories of Buddhism. Through the use of primary and secondary literature, film, and other media, this course will provide a regional overview of the development of Buddhism from ancient India to contemporary Western society. While we will try to follow the chronological development of Buddhism since antiquity, the focus of this course is more concerned with addressing key components that have shaped many different culturally specific Buddhist practices and doctrines. Course participants will be exposed to many of the unique philosophical, doctrinal, practical nuances and distinctions resulting from these cultural adaptations.
courses.learning_outcomes:
This course will enable course participants to:

Knowledge Outcomes

(1)display adequate understanding of core Buddhist concepts and identify distinctions between various Buddhist practices, doctrines, and histories

(2)demonstrate critical reflections on the relation between Buddhist teachings and worldly values

Attitude Outcomes

(3)develop sensitivities and awareness of cross-cultural issues and begin to understand how they have shaped Buddhism into various modes of doctrines and practices

(4)nurture a larger sensitivity to the value of Buddhist practice in human life

Skill Outcomes

(5)develop improved writing skills to better articulate the data/questions/issues extracted from course readings and discussions;
(6)develop skills necessary for close textual readings and analysis of relevant materials.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Religion and Food
courses.description: This course explores the intersection of beliefs/worldviews, health, and dietary practices in various religious traditions. Students will examine how different religious beliefs and customs shape the relationship between food and health within these traditions. The course will provide a comprehensive understanding of the impact of religious beliefs on dietary restrictions, rituals, and the overall well-being of individuals practicing these religions.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

* Understand the beliefs and customs that influence food choices and restrictions in various religions.
* Understand the cultural and social aspects of food consumption within religious communities.
* Critically analyse the dietary practices of different religious traditions, including Judaism, Islam, Buddhism, Taoism, Christianity, and Hinduism.
* Critically analyse the role of food in expressing faith and spirituality within religious communities.
* Evaluate the impact of religious dietary practices on health and well-being.
* Apply the concept of fasting as a religious practice and its effects on physical and mental health.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Gender and Sexuality in Religions
courses.description: Are religion and sex always at odds? How can religious aspects such as symbols, myths, taboos, rituals, and practices help us understand body, healing, medicine, gender fluidity, and sexual practices?Rather than simply dividing religions into different traditions, this course takes a thematic approach and examines religion, gender and sexuality as crucial systems of power that shape our world. Students will develop an understanding of religion and gender as both subjects and as categories of analysis. As categories of analysis, students will use gender and religion to interrogate cultural production and social systems, paying close attention to how gender and religion intersect with other categories of social difference. Students will connect the assigned academic readings to “real-life” examples in the news, media, and their own lives, thereby producing new theoretical understandings of gender, religion, and sexuality in the contexts of Hong Kong, Asia, and the world.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

1. Identify key scholars in the field and their theories, both classic and emerging
2. Demonstrate in depth knowledge of religion and gender as intersectional categories of analysis
3. Actively reflect upon ordinary/accepted modes of thinking about gender, sexuality and religion, construct new modes of thinking oriented toward change
4. Demonstrate a critical, intersectional awareness of gender and religion in the social and cultural contexts of Hong Kong, Asia, and the world
5. Develop critical reading skills of academic literature on religion and gender, including reading, analysing, and summarising the argument of secondary literature; selecting and analysing primary materials including visual contents
6. Develop communication skills through class discussion and writing assignments
7. Develop research skills
8. Develop transferrable skills

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Intermediate Latin
courses.description: This course builds upon foundational Latin skills to develop students' proficiency in reading and analyzing Latin texts. Assuming basic Latin competency, we will advance through increasingly complex grammatical structures, with particular emphasis on: Middle and passive voices, Infinitive constructions, Subjunctive clauses and their sequence, Participial phrases and ablative absolute, Gerunds and gerundives, Complex relative clauses, Indirect discourse, and Conditional sentences.The course centers on intensive study of selected classical prose, primarily from Cicero and Seneca, supplemented by readings from other classical authors. These authors provide an excellent progression in syntactical complexity while offering varied prose styles. Through these readings, students will strengthen their command of advanced Latin grammar, expand their vocabulary, and develop sophisticated translation techniques. Special attention will be given to developing sight-reading skills and mastering complex syntactical structures. By the end of the course, students will be prepared to approach advanced Latin literature with greater confidence and analytical skill.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisites: CURE2154 or 2166 or 2167 or its equivalent
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Demonstrate mastery of advanced Latin grammar, including complex verbal systems and clause constructions
2. Apply comprehensive Latin vocabulary knowledge and understand word formation patterns and derivatives
3. Read and comprehend elementary to intermediate-level Latin prose from classical authors with proper attention to style
4. Analyze and translate unseen Latin texts of moderate difficulty with accurate grammatical explanation

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Latin for Law, Social Sciences and Humanities
courses.description: Latin for Law, Social Sciences and Humanities introduces students to fundamental Latin language structures while focusing on terminology essential to social sciences, humanities, and legal studies. This course requires no prior knowledge of Latin and welcomes students from all academic backgrounds. While particularly relevant for those pursuing studies in law, social sciences, humanities, and related fields, the course provides all students with valuable insights into social, cultural, and legal concepts through the lens of Latin terminology.The course is structured in two complementary components. The first develops core Latin language competency, covering essential grammar including noun declensions, verb conjugations, and basic syntax. The second component applies this linguistic foundation to specialized vocabulary and concepts across disciplines, including philosophical terminology, psychological concepts, legal principles, sociological terms, and historical discourse. Students will learn to analyze and construct complex terms through understanding Latin roots, prefixes, and suffixes common in humanities and social science discourse. By course completion, students will be able to comprehend and correctly use Latin-derived terminology in academic and professional contexts, while acquiring sufficient Latin language foundation to pursue intermediate Latin studies if desired.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

1. Demonstrate basic understanding of Latin grammatical structures, including fundamental noun declensions, basic verb conjugations, and simple sentence patterns essential for analyzing academic and legal terms
2. Recognize and explain common Latin roots, prefixes, and suffixes frequently encountered in legal, social sciences, and humanities terminology
3. Correctly interpret basic Latin phrases and terminology commonly used in legal documents, philosophical texts, and academic discourse in social sciences and humanities
4. Apply basic Latin language skills to decipher unfamiliar academic and professional terms by breaking them down into their component parts
5. Connect fundamental Latin expressions to modern concepts in law, social sciences, and humanities, demonstrating awareness of how classical Latin influences contemporary academic and professional discourse

courses.description: The classics of different religions offer a wealth of insight and wisdom about nature, reality and life. Reading important religious classics is an essential way to acquire an in-depth understanding of the crucial doctrines and philosophy of a religion. This course gives students a chance to critically read classics, in their original languages or in translation, from one to two of the following religious traditions: Daoism, Buddhism, Christianity, Islam and Hinduism. The texts will be analyzed with a focus on their religious thoughts, and the traditions and skills of interpreting respective classics. Texts selected for reading may include Zhuangzi, The Heart Sutra, The Bible and The Quran, The Bhagavad Gītā, and religiously inspired literary classics such as The Divine Comedy and The Journey to the West. The exact choice of texts will be decided by the teacher who offers the course in a particular year.
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the end of the course, students should:

1. be able to read, understand and analyse samples of religious classics, with an awareness of the underlying cultural, social and historical contexts.

2. have reached a good awareness of the textual study of a specific religious tradition, and be familiar with the main relevant resources.

3. have acquired the basic linguistic and methodological skills to undertake independent research on religious texts, working on primary sources.

4. have improved basic academic skills, including critical reading, research, writing, and discussion skills.

They are also invited to provide suggestions for enhancing teaching and learning effect, as well as reviews of their difficulties in taking the course. An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Classical Arabic for Beginners I
courses.description: With the study of designed texts and relevant passages from the Qur'an, this module introduces students to the fundamental grammar and syntax that both Classical and Modern Literary Arabic are commonly shared. Students are first introduced to the Arabic script, followed by the rudiments of Arabic grammar and syntax. To keep this course relevant and interesting, some Arabic phrases and dialogues in daily conversations will also be taught.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CURE2151 (Arabic Beginners I)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon the completion of this course, students are expected to:

The course provides ample opportunities to make considerable development towards the comprehension of the Arabic language in general and Qur'anic Arabic in particular.

The graded introduction of Arabic grammar and syntax will intensify the understanding of the language and create confidence among students in a non-Arabic speaking environment.

Student's skills are developed towards the comprehension of unvocalized Arabic text and translation of unseen Arabic text.
courses.course_syllabus:
The course covers the characteristics of Arabic scripts; the nature of noun including Idafah; personal pronoun and pronoun suffix; preposition and some special particles like Inna and Kana and its sisters; perfect and imperfect verbs and its derived forms, verbal noun including active and passive

participles; moods including the indicative, jussive and subjunctive; imperative and prohibition; sound and broken plurals; adverbs of time and place and numbers etc.

End-of-term university course evaluation will be conducted in class.

Students' comments and feedback on the course through e-mails or personal meeting with the instructor are always welcomed.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Classical Arabic for Beginners II
courses.description: The course 'Classical Arabic for Beginners II ' is suitable for students who have studied CURE2151 Arabic for Beginners I or CURE2180 Classical Arabic for Begninners I. This course aims to continue the learning of grammar and syntax that both Classical and Modern Literary Arabic are shared through writing, reading, listening, conversation, and through the study of relevant passages from the Qur'an. The learning of Arabic grammar and sentence structure is also consolidated. By the end of the course, students are expected to have basic proficiency of the Classical Arabic language.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduction to Indian Religions
courses.description: India among its one-billion population arguably represents the world's greatest diversity in religious and cultural thought, practice, and expression. This course aims to bring students in touch with the major religious traditions and cultural patterns of India. It also aims to awaken appreciation and understanding of how diverse peoples of India negotiate their lives within this complex religious and cultural landscape. The main question and thematic thread running through the course will be how the various traditions understand, express, and practice embodiment and transcendence. In other words, what are the constituents, changes, relationships, and possibilities for human beings and divinities with reference to the temporal world and transcendent reality? Where can we find significant "family resemblances" – without ignoring differences – among the diversities of persons and sub-traditions within those roughly designated Hindu, Jain, Buddhist, Muslim, Sikh, or Christian?
courses.learning_outcomes:
As a way to understand important dimensions of religion in general this course aims to expose students to aspects of Indian ‘spirituality,’ or the varied ways people of India understand and pursue ‘higher purpose’ and ultimacy. Having seriously engaged with the course students can expect to have:

1) A basic acquaintance with religious ideas and practice in the Indian subcontinental context.

2) A basic ability to grasp the feel and logic of traditions of spirituality in India sympathetically yet critically.

3) A basic competence in reading, listening, speaking and writing about the topics treated in the course.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introducing the course

2. Foundational sacred texts: Vedas and Upanishads

3. The Epics: Ramayana and Mahabharata

4. The spirit of devotion: The Bhagavad-gita and the Bhagavata Purana.

5. Paths of Self-discipline and Knowledge: Yoga & Vedanta

6. Vishnu, Siva, and the Goddess: Receivers of bhakti, facilitators of tantra

7. Festivals and pilgrimage: Celebrating movement and change.

8. Jain ‘worldlessness’: ways of preserving and ending life.

9. Early Buddhism: breaking away from Brahmanism

10. Voices of surrender: Muslim ways of spirituality in India

11. The Adi-Granth: Sikh ways of community-building and asserting identity

12. Christianity and interreligious encounter in India

13. Final class discussion
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students will be encouraged to communicate their evaluations of the course, especially as this is part of a completely new development of Indian studies at CUHK. Details of how evaluations can be communicated will be given during the course.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduction to Islam
courses.description: This course aims to give students an understanding of Islam as a religion along with an insight into the crucial issues facing Muslims throughout the world today. The course introduces the beginnings of Islam by looking at pre-Islamic Mecca, the life of the prophet Muhammad, and the revelation of the Qur'an. The beliefs and practices of Muslims are explored through an indepth look at the five pillars of Islam. The variety of Islamic beliefs will be discussed in an investigation of Shi'i and Sufi traditions. The course concludes with contemporary issues of Islam in the world, interfaith connections, the place of women in Islam, and the presence of Muslims as political minorities in the West. In addition to this structure, local references to Islam in Hong Kong will be used to give an enhanced local perspective to these topics.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To be able to understand religion in its historical settings and contemporary contexts of modern living; globally and locally and to analyze how contemporary religious expressions shape and are shaped by global and local cultural, social, and political trends.

Ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of religious traditions especially those one does not belong.
courses.course_syllabus:
第一周: 跟同学见面，了解同学的水平及感兴趣的问题，以便备课。另外，介绍本课的授课方法及要求。

第二周: 伊斯兰的基本信仰

六大信仰： 信真主、信天使、信经典、信圣人、信后世、信前定。

第三周: 伊斯兰的基本功修

五桩天命：念、礼、斋、课、朝

第四周: 伊斯兰的主要特点：

一神论、入世性、全面性、科学性

第五周: 伊斯兰的禁忌和节日

行为的禁忌：举伴真主（以物配主）、伤害他人的生命和利益、撒谎、奸淫等。
饮食的禁忌：饮食的原则、清真的概念、不能饮食的物种。
穿着的禁忌：穿着的原则，“羞体”的概念和含义、男人的服装、女人的服装。

第六周: 伊斯兰的教派与学派

教派：笋尼派和什叶派
学派：哈乃非派、沙费埃派、马力克派和罕百里派。
中国的伊斯兰教派：格迪目、门宦、伊赫瓦尼、赛莱夫。

第七周: 伊斯兰的渊源：宗教的源头、“天启”的历史、《古兰经》与《圣经》、古兰经与圣训。

第八周:伊斯兰教与基督宗教的关系和异同

伊斯兰教-基督教-犹太教的关系、伊斯兰教与基督教的异同、伊斯兰教与天主教的异同。

第九周:伊斯兰与世界和平、穆斯林的人生理想、恐怖主义及其根源、伊斯兰的仁爱观

第十周: 伊斯兰教中妇女的社会地位、妇女的权利和义务、男女的平等问题。

第十一周: 伊斯兰与原教旨主义：原教旨主义的起源、原教旨主义的含义、原教旨主义的表现形式。

第十二周: 伊斯兰与贫穷落后：伊斯兰与商业经济、伊斯兰与教育、伊斯兰与科学、穆斯林落后的根源。

第十三周:伊斯兰文化面面观：文学、建筑、绘画、书法、哲学、医学、化学

第十四周:同学自己感兴趣的话题(开放)

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduction to Taoism
courses.description: This course aims at introducing Taoism as a Chinese religion embedded with ancient Chinese religious culture. Topics of the study will cover history of main Taoist sects, Taoist divinity, Taoist conceptions of immortality and life and death, Taoist ritual and Taoist canonization.
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students should have the knowledge to:

- understand basic concepts in Taoist Studies

- understand the development of Taoism from the Han until contemporary period

- understand Taoism in Hong Kong today
courses.course_syllabus:
1) 道教研究﹕歷史、方法與困難

2) 什麼是道教：道教(哲學)、方仙道與道教的關係

3) 東漢天師道教團的形成及發展

4) 六朝江南道教(上)﹕葛洪《抱朴子內篇》的神仙思想

5) 六朝江南道教(下)﹕上清經(派)及靈寶經(派)

6) 唐代道教的發展﹕道教經典及道觀、道士制度的統一

7) 宋、明、清道教的發展﹕新興道派與全真道

8) 道教的神譜及宇宙觀

9) 道教的生死觀、救濟觀及倫理觀

10) 道教的齋醮科儀制度

11) 道藏的形成及源流

12) 近代道教﹕中國、香港及台灣的發展

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Religious Traditions and Politics of the Arab World
courses.description: The "Arab World" today refers to a large geographical area: from the Atlantic coast of North Africa in the West to the border of Iran in the East. Arabic is the principal spoken language of this region, which is also linked by shared cultural and religious traditions. The course presents a historical survey of the "Arab World" from pre-Islamic times to the modern era. The first part of this survey the rise and spread of Arab political rule and Arab language and culture with the advent of Islam in the 7th century, with later emphasis on some of the principal political, economic, social, religious, and cultural developments and their relevance to the contemporary "Middle East" region. Two main themes referred to throughout the course will be the unity and diversity of the "Arab World" and how various Arab cultures and societies have interacted with other peoples in this region and beyond.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

Knowledge Outcomes

Understand religion in its historical settings and contemporary contexts of modern living. Understand religion in its many facets.

Engage in a critical analysis of religions by the methods of the humanities and social sciences especially through historiographical studies. Recognize central themes and issues in the Arab World, especially with respect to cultural and religious dimensions.

Skills Outcomes

Communicate and present (orally and in writing).

Gather, organize, deploy, synthesize and evaluate different types of evidence and information.

Claim English proficiency in reading and writing with accurate referencing and clarity of expression. Demonstrate cross-cultural understanding and intercultural literacy.

Attitude Outcomes

Have awareness of plurality and multi-faceted complexity within Arab cultural, political and religious traditions, and of the issues of multiple and conflicting interpretations of language and symbols, texts and traditions.

Acknowledge the contested and provisional nature of knowledge and understanding. Show tolerance of diverse positions and have respect for others' views.

Have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of religious and cultural traditions, political viewpoints and ideological positions, especially those one does not belong.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to the Course – Overview; Who are the Arabs? Week 2: Pre-Islamic Arabia and the Byzantine/Sassanian Near East

Late Antiquity: The Byzantines and Sassanians; Arabia and the Near East on the Eve of Islam – Conflict, Tribalism, and the Jahiliyya Age

Week 3: Muhammad and the Birth of the Muslim Community

The Prophet, Revelation, and the Early Muslim Community; The Constitution of Medina and the First Islamic State

Week 4: Successors to the Prophet

The Rashidun Caliphs; Ridda Wars, Fitna, and Conquest

Week 5: The Umayyad Caliphate

The Umayyads, Reforms, and the Rise of the ʿUlamāʾ

Week 6: The Abbasid Caliphate

The Establishment of the Abbasid Caliphate; The Abbasid "Golden Age": House of Wisdom, Baghdad and Samarra

Week 7: Rival Caliphates: The Fatimids and Muslim Spain

Ismaʿili Shiʿism; The Rise of the Fatimids; Shi'i Propaganda; Fatimid Cairo; Alamut; Umayyad Rule in Al-Andalus

Week 8: The Age of Sultans and Crusades

Abbasid Fragmentation and the Rise of Sultanates: Seljuks, Zengids,and Ayyubids; C rusade and Jihad: Jerusalem, the Crusader Kingdoms, and the Muslim Response

Week 9: Coming of the Turks and Mongols

Mamluk Egypt; The Black Death; Mongol Conquest of Baghdad

Week 10: The Ottoman Age

Gunpowder Empires; Conquest of Constantinople; Ottoman Expansion

Week 11: The Colonial Age and Arab Responses

Napoleon; French and British Rivalries; Rise of Arab Kingdoms and Emirates

Week 12: Making of the Modern Middle East

World Wars; Zionism; Pan-Arab Nationalism; Pan-Islamism; The Cold War

Week 13: Contemporary Reflections

The Arab Spring; Extremism and Regional Conflict

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Chinese Temples and Festivals
courses.description: (UGEC2500 is double-coded with CURE2375.)  This course is a study of Chinese temples and festivals. Temples are cultural heritages which preserve as mute testimony to local history. Their structures and the use of ornaments also reflect traditional architectural characteristics. "Jie dan" (festivals), including birthdays of the gods and jiao rituals, are the ritual activities being held for prosperity in folk culture. The belief system, indigenous custom, human diasporas as well as community cohesiveness of the Chinese can be illustrated from both temples and festivals in China and Hong Kong.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Religions, Violence and Peace
courses.description: Conflict seems a natural activity of human beings. It commonly results from contrasting ideas, perceptions or limited resources. It widely appears in diverse issues such as family ties, social justice, political ideologies or environmental concerns. This course is designed to provide students a process of (1) analyzing the assumptions, sources, and types of interpersonal, inter-group, and international conflict with the ideas of race, ethnicity, religion, and culture; (2) studying various forms of non-violent conflict resolution, and (3) studying both the relationships between religion and peace building.
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completion of the course, students are able to:

1. analyze the many facets of conflict and how conflict plays a role in human history and in our daily lives ;
2. discuss ideas about the value of conflict (e.g. that it can be constructive, relationship building, and necessary for growth and change);
3. study systematic means of conflict resolution and investigate alternatives of non-violent problem solving.
4. apply religious and moral values to issues of justice and peace.

完成此課程後，學生能夠：
1. 分析衝突的不同面相及其在人類歷史和日常生活中的角色；
2. 了解衝突的價值所在（如，衝突可以是建設性的、有利建立關係、或是發展及變遷所需的）；
3. 探索解決衝突的系統化途徑和非暴力的問題解決方法；
4. 運用宗教與倫理的價值到公義、和平等議題上。
courses.course_syllabus:
Week/Topic/Key Concepts
Course Syllabus

1) Overview the Course
What is conflict? Value /Price of conflict

Part I: Types of Conflict
2) Identity Based Conflict
Defining the term identity; categories of identity; in-group and out-group; conformity or obedience to Power

3)Race/Religion/Culture/Ethnicity and Conflict
Defining terms: ethnic, nationalism, religion; community/ethnic/religious conflicts in history

4)Market Economy and Conflict
Globalization, Competition and oppression; Economic justice; Spirituality in marketplace

Part II: Models of Conflict Resolution
5)Interest-Based Negotiation
Introduction to conflict resolution mechanisms; Positions to interests; Getting to interests

6)Mediation
What is Meditation? Roles of the Mediator; Stages, processes, and phases of mediation; When is it appropriate?

7)Group Conflict Resolution
Organizational conflict resolution; Community based conflict resolution

8)Diverse Methods: Political Protest, Civil Disobedience and Diplomacy
Defining terms; Gandhi; Martin Luther King; Liberation Theologies; WTO; Hong Kong cases

9)Religious Approaches to Conflict: Christianity, Buddhism and Muslim
Non-Violence, non-violent resistance, and "just-war theory"

Part III: Religion and Peace Building
10)Peace-building, Human Rights and Civil Society
Roles of religion and spirituality in peacemaking; Comparing practices of faith-based advocacy for social justice, reconciliation, and coexistence; Exploring both obstacles and opportunities faced by religious peace-builders

11)Religious Approach to Peace Building I: Christianity
Current Christian approaches to peacemaking in areas of conflict: War and militarism, crime, poverty, racism, and gender relations.

12)Religious Approach to Peace Building II: Asia Religious Practitioners’ Approach to Peace Building
Spirituality and peace Building; Compassion; Dalai Lama, Ven. Thich Nhat Hanh, and Ikeda Daisaku (池田大作); Taoist Approaches to Peace

13)Conclusion and Reflection
