courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Art Institutions in Twentieth-Century China
courses.description: The course examines the correlation between art and institutions in twentieth-century China, aiming to encourage students to think about modern Chinese art through the concept of the artworld. The downfall of the Qing dynasty and the establishment of the Republican China transformed the social and institutional organisation of the production, distribution, and consumption of art as well as the traditional patronage system in modern China. The structural changes conditioned the emergence of formal and informal art institutions that facilitated yet constrained artistic practices, laying the foundation for the development of a modern art world in China. The course looks at the history of modern Chinese art and the formation of different art institutions in the sociocultural and economic context of modern China. Weekly topics are structured chronologically and thematically, which cover a wide range of themes, including art schools, art societies, museums, exhibitions, and art market. Adopting an interdisciplinary approach, the course offers students multi-perspectives to understand the transformation of modern Chinese art and the interactions between artistic practices and society in modern China.
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Explain the theory of the artworld and history of art institutions in modern China.

• Identify and describe the historical background, aesthetics, and social factors reflected in specific artworks.

• Identify and interpret the correlation between artistic styles and the institutional organisation.

• Reflect upon the roles of art institutions in the process of art creation, production, distribution and consumption.

• Select research materials and develop original research topics on modern Chinese art.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: The Theory of the Artworld and the Emergence of a Modern Art World in China

Howard Becker, “Art Worlds and Collective Activity”, in Art Worlds 25th Ed. (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2008), 1-39.

Roberta Wue, “Introduction”, Art Worlds: Artists, Images, and Audiences in Late Nineteenth-Century Shanghai (Hong Kong: Hong Kong University Press, 2014), 1-21.

2. The Interaction between art creation and dynamic urban culture in major Chinese cities

Jonathan Hay, “Painting and the Built Environment in Late Nineteenth-Century Shanghai”, Maxwell Hearn ed., Chinese Art Modern Expressions (New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art, 2001), 61-101.

Wen-hsin Yeh, “The Shanghai Gaze: Visual Culture and Images of Modernity”, Jason Kuo ed., Visual Culture in Shanghai 1850s-1930s (Washington: New Academia Publishing, 2007), 333-45.

3. How was art taught through the newly established educational system and curriculum?

Mayching Kao, “Reforms in Education and the Beginning of the Western-Style Painting Movement in China”, in Julia Andrews and Kuiyi Shen ed., A Century in Crisis: Modernity and Tradition in the Art of Twentieth-Century China (New York: Guggenheim Museum, 1998), 146-171.

Jane Zheng, “Private Tutorial Art Schools in the Shanghai Market Economy: The Shanghai Art School, 1913-1919”, Modern China 35, 3 (2009): 313-343.

4. Artistic network: art societies and their functions

Zheng Shengtian, “Waves Lashed the Bund from the West Shanghai’s Art Scene in the 1930s”, in Jo-Anne Birnie Danzker, Ken Lum and Zheng Shengtian eds., Shanghai Modern, 1919-1945 (Munich: Museum Villa Stuck, 2004), 174-99.

Julia Andrews and Kuiyi Shen, “Traditionalism as a Modern Stance: The Chinese Women’s Calligraphy and Painting Society”, Modern Chinese Literature and Culture 11, no. 1 (1999): 1-30.

5. Publishing culture: a new way to disseminate artworks and generate public discourse

Waara, Carrie, “Invention, Industry, Art: The Commercialisation of Culture in Republican Art Magazines.” In Sherman Cochrane ed., Inventing Nanjing Road: Commercial Culture in Shanghai, 1900-1945 (Ithaca, NY: East Asian Program, Cornell University, 1999), 61-89

Richard Vinograd, “Patrimonies in Press: Art Publishing, Cultural Politics, and Canon Construction in the Career of Di Baoxian”, in Joshua Fogel ed., The Role of Japan in Modern Chinese Art (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2012), 245-272.

6. New technology: the introduction of photography and its impact on art

Liu Yu-Jen, “Second Only to the Original: Rhetoric and Practice in the Photographic Reproduction of Art in Early Twentieth-Century China”, Art History 37, 1 (February 2014): 68-95.

Gu Yi, “What’s in a Name? Photography and the Reinvention of Visual Truth in China, 1840-1911”, The Art Bulletin XCV, 1 (March 2013):120-38.

7. How did museum change the perception and presentation of art?

Christopher Whitehead, “Establishing the Manifesto: Art Histories in the Nineteenth-century Museum”, Simon Knell, Suzanne MacLeod and Sheila Watson eds., Museum Revolutions: How Museums Change and are Changed (London: Routledge, 2007), 48-60.

Lisa Claypool, “Zhang Jian and China’s First Museum”, Journal of Asian Studies 64, no. 3 (August, 2005): 567-604.

8. Constructing the national identity through international exhibitions

Michaela Pejcochova, “The First Exhibitions and the Origins of Collecting Modern Chinese Art in Europe”, Bulletin of the National Gallery in Prague, XXVII (2017): 6-22.

Eric Lefebvre, “Ways to Modernity: Chinese Artists in Paris”, in Paris. Chinese Painting: Legacy of the 20th Century Chinese Masters (Hong Kong: Hong Kong Museum of Art, 2014), 24-37.

9. Field Trip to Museum. Through a guided tour, students will be able to apply the knowledge acquired from the course to evaluate and review selected artworks.

10. Collecting activities and the formation of collections of modern Chinese art

Jean Baudrillard, “The System of Collecting”, John Elsner and Roger Cardinal eds., The Cultures of Collecting (London: Reaktion Books, 1994), 7-24.

Zaixin Hong, “Florence Ayscough: pioneer promoter of modern Chinese painting in America”, Jason Steuber and Guolong Lai eds., Collectors, Collections & Collecting the Arts of China (Florida: University Press of Florida, 2014), 119-50.

11. Art and its audience: the consumption and reception of art

Shih Shou-chien 石守謙, “Huihua guanzhong yu guonan: ershi shiji qianqi Zhongguo huajia de yasu jueze 繪畫、觀眾與國難：二十世紀前期中國畫家的雅俗抉擇 [Painting, Audience and National Crisis: A Choice between Elegance and Vulgarity of Chinese Artists in the Early Twentieth Century].” Meishushi yanjiu jikan 美術史研究集刊 [Journal of the Study of Art History] 21 (2006): 151-88.

Craig Clunas, “The Nation”, in Chinese Painting and Its Audiences (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2017), 155-191.

12. Art market: professional intermediaries and a new patronage system

Kuiyi Shen, “Patronage and the Beginning of a Modern Art World in Late Qing Shanghai,” in Jason Kuo ed., In Visual Culture in Shanghai 1850s-1930s (Washington D. C.: New Academia Pub., 2007), 13-27.

Pedith Chan, “The Business of Art: The Art Market”, in The Making of A Modern Art World: Institutionalisation and Legitimisation of Guohua in Republican Shanghai (Leiden: Brill, 2017), 186-259.

13. The structure of the Chinese artworld since the Mao era and Wrap Up

Julia Andrews and Kuiyi Shen, “Art after Mao, 1976-1989”, in The Art of Modern China (Berkeley: University of California Press, 2012), 201-223.

Svetlana Kharchenkova, Nataliya Komarova, and Olav Velthuis, “Official Art Organizations in the Emerging Markets of China and Russia”, in Olav Velthuis and Stefano Baia Curioni eds., Cosmopolitan Canvases: Globalization of Markets for Contemporary Art (Oxford: Oxford University Press, 2015), 78-101.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduction to Heritage Management
courses.description: Cultural heritage management presents a complex landscape influenced by globalization, urbanization, cultural place-making projects, technological advancements, economic development, and diverse applications in both the preservation of history and the creative industries. As cities expand and integrate globally, the challenge of preserving local cultural identities while balancing heritage conservation with modern urban needs becomes increasingly significant. In recent years, technological innovations and the development of smart cities have enhanced accessibility and supported cultural initiatives, transforming heritage preservation. However, issues of sustainability and resilience in dynamic urban environments worldwide have also emerged as critical topics and debates within cultural heritage management.This course aims to provide students with an introductory knowledge of cultural heritage management, along with the theoretical frameworks that shape our understanding of cultural heritage. It covers policy at international, national, and local levels, conservation and restoration practices, funding and resource management, and ethical considerations. While highlighting the significance of intangible cultural heritage, this course will also examine the impact of tourism and the vital role of community involvement, intersecting with issues of identity, technology, urban planning, and conflict. By offering a variety of foundational concepts and real-world case studies, students will gain a comprehensive understanding of current practices and challenges in cultural heritage management.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Not for students who have taken CUMT2004, UGED2285.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Explore key historical and contemporary examples of cultural heritage projects, along with the theoretical frameworks that shape our understanding of cultural heritage.
* Understand cultural heritage policy at international, national, and local levels, with a focus on conservation and restoration practices, funding, and resource management.
* Examine critical issues related to the preservation, interpretation, and dissemination of heritage, including ethical considerations.
* Develop skills to critically analyze intangible heritage, assess the impact of tourism, and understand the vital role of community involvement.
* Reflect on broader issues concerning identity, technology, urban planning, and conflict as they relate to cultural heritage management.
* Cultivate an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions within existing methods of preserving, interpreting, and disseminating heritage.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *1. Introduction to Cultural Heritage Management**

• Definitions and scope of cultural heritage management

• Historical development of cultural heritage management practices

* *2. Theories and Concepts in Cultural Heritage**

• Key concepts in cultural heritage studies

* *3. Legislation and Policy in Cultural Heritage**

• Overview of international, national, and local heritage laws and policies

• The role of governmental and non-governmental organizations

* *4. Funding and Resource Management**

• Financial management and fundraising

• Grants, sponsorships, and other funding sources

* *5. Heritage Site Management, Conservation, and Restoration**

• Techniques and strategies for managing cultural heritage sites

• Principles and practices of conserving and restoring cultural heritage

* *6. Intangible Cultural Heritage**

• Understanding and managing intangible cultural heritage

• Traditions, rituals, and oral histories

* *7. Cultural Heritage and Tourism**

• Heritage sites and tourism

• Economic and social impacts of tourism

* *8. Community Involvement in Heritage Management**

• Engaging local communities in the management of cultural heritage

• Interpretive programs and exhibitions in heritage education

* *9. Cultural Heritage and Identity**

• The role of cultural heritage in shaping cultural identities

• Issues of representation and inclusivity in cultural heritage

* *10. Digital Heritage and Technology**

• The use of technologies in the management of cultural heritage

• Digital preservation and access to cultural heritage

* *11. Cultural Heritage and Urban Planning**

• Urban and regional planning

• Balancing development and preservation in urban environments

* *12. Ethical Issues in Cultural Heritage Management**

* Ethical dilemmas and considerations in preservation

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Management of Public and Non-profit Cultural Organization
courses.description: Public and non-profit cultural organizations are positioned in the core part of traditional arts management education. This course aims to equip students with knowledge on the characteristics of public and non-profit cultural organizations as one type of cultural organizations, and mastery of the key management components of public and non-profit cultural organizations, including strategic planning, structural design, human resource management, leadership building, financial planning and fiscal management, marketing cultural products, and the organizations’ internal and external control and performance evaluation. A series of in-class exercises and individual and group projects is designed to develop students’ knowledge and management skills simultaneously.
courses.learning_outcomes: In terms of knowledge, students are expected to gain an understanding of the specificities of public and non-profit cultural management, which are different from general management based on the understanding of the characteristics of those organizations and the profession. Students are also expected to achieve an overall picture of all the key components in non-profit cultural organization management. More emphasis, however, is placed on the students’ capacity to apply the knowledge of management to practice by enriching solid skills. Through this course, students can design the structure of a cultural organization, plan for strategies for organizational development, and enact internal and external controls. Their major final product will be a business plan for creating and managing a non-profit cultural organization. In addition, the students can acquire software technical training to develop portfolio design and job application skills.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Understanding Public and Non-profit Cultural Organizations and the Course Overview
This introductory section provides a macroscopic view of the profession of arts management to illustrate what the business of arts and entertainment. The section also enumerates the sectors, explores the history of the profession, as well as provides students an initial understanding of cultural organization, the distinction between profit and non-profit cultural organization, and the common elements of cultural organizations. Furthermore, this section provides a synopsis of the structure of this course and other major issues.

2. Cultural Organization Typology and Functions of the Major Types of Non-profit Cultural Organizations
This section discusses first the method for classifying cultural organizations and the characteristics of each type of cultural organization, which is the knowledge that has been introduced in the course of CUMT1001 “Introduction to Cultural Management.” Two major types of non-profit cultural organizations are then illustrated, namely, visual arts and performing arts organizations. Specific areas, organizational goals, and functions of visual and performing arts organizations are elaborated to illustrate the points.
Tutorial: Conduct open-ended discussions about students’ perception of Hong Kong’s non-profit cultural organizations.

3. Management Thoughts and their Application to Arts Organizations
In this section, management thoughts and theories integrated with scientific management are scanned with a review of early management practices and concepts along a historical timeline of disciplinary development. The application of management thoughts to the arts is discussed, with a distinction between general management and arts management. The contribution of arts management to general management at four key management components (i.e., strategic management, human resource management, finance and accounting, and marketing and consumer behavior studies) is also discussed. In addition, this section presents an open system approach to understanding a cultural organization, which interacts with the external environment. Museums and theaters are used as two cases to study the structure of a cultural organization. In the tutorial, students are taught to design the structure of an organization.
Tutorial: Design an open system structure of a cultural organization, Byrnes, 2009, 167-159.
Assignment: Conduct small-scale research about a cultural organization (by interview or secondary data collection).

4. Creating Arts Organization I: Development of Arts Organizations
What should an organization founder do and what are the strategies and approaches that should be considered in establishing an arts organization from scratch? This section determines the varied ways by which cultural organizations are established and organized. The external and internal factors that affect the structuring of cultural organizations and pending on the for-profit and not-for-profit nature of the businesses are discussed. Furthermore, this section introduces the concept of life cycle and evaluates its implication for the creation and development of cultural organizations. In addition to formal cultural organizations, the way to organize projects, including its phasing and matrix structuring, is also discussed.
Tutorial: Discuss the ways by which a cultural organization is structured based on the students’ assignment in Lecture 3.
Assignment: Conduct a case study on cultural organization (by interview or secondary data collection) and compare it to the knowledge taught in class.

5. Creating Arts Organization II: Planning Strategies and Decision Making
This section discusses planning and decision-making process and methods in cultural organizations. It also introduces a strategic planning process, which consists of the mission statement, mission analysis, vision statement, resource analysis, and the methods to formulate strategies. In addition, this section introduces a decision-making process by outlining the procedure of making choices and problem solving. These methods and processes are summarized with a sample of decision making and planning process. Examples of business plans and project plans are provided.
Tutorial: Discuss students’ designs of a cultural organization.
Assignment: Plan developing strategies for the organization and revise the organizational structure according to the strategies. Write Items 4, 5, and 7.1 for the business plan, Byrnes, 2009, 32–33.

6. Human Resource Management
This section discusses the process of staffing a cultural organization, which comprises four steps. Step 1 is about conducting job analysis to determine the need for the positions and the major functions of jobs and specify duties and analyze the tasks. Step 2 describes and posts jobs. In Step 3, candidates are selected and recruited according to a set of due courses and criteria. Finally, job details and functions are reviewed and job trainings are provided in Step 4. Based on this lecture, additional advices about job hunting and application are provided. The second half of this lecture focuses on the issue of volunteer recruitment and management, such as discussing volunteer determinants, decisions to volunteers, and volunteer activities. A theater regarding a production team is shown.
Tutorial: Conduct an “in-design” software technical training.
Assignment 1: Write Items 7.2 and 7.3 in the business plan.
Assignment 2: Create a personal profile for job application.

7. Roles of Art Managers and Leadership in Cultural Organizations
The career path and the professional profile of an art manager comprise another important factor that shapes cultural organizations. The first part of this section discusses the profile of arts managers, their personal mission, and their role in a cultural organization. The second part discusses power and leadership modes and outlines the mainstream theories of leadership and motivation. Dual leadership in museum management is particularly highlighted.
Tutorial: Conduct an in-class quiz.

8. Fiscal Management I: The Operations
This section focuses on two important dimensions in organizational control system, namely, budgeting and financial planning. The budgeting process is explained with a categorization of budgets and detailed budgets. For the financial management in cultural organizations, pricing cultural products is discussed first to maximize the revenues and then the accounting system, after which other financial management issues are illustrated. Both museum and theater budgeting are used as examples.
Tutorial: Conduct class reviews and discussions about the quiz and the two assignments.
Assignment 1: Write Item 8 in the business plan.

9. Fiscal Management II: Fundraising Strategies in Cultural Organizations
This section introduces the methods used in raising funds for a cultural organization. Such methods teach students how to make fundraising plans as part of the strategic planning for cultural organizations. Afterwards, a series of fundraising skills is then introduced. The methods to control fundraising costs are also discussed. Fundraising in museums exemplifies the knowledge in discussion.
Tutorial: Discuss the fiscal plan.

10. Marketing and Arts I: Approaches and Strategies
This section goes over the knowledge taught in CUMT 1001, including the shift in the concept of marketing from an inappropriate use of money to the essential selling-out of the cultural products of organizations, marketing theories, approaches, and processes geared toward developing the students’ understanding of cultural organization marketing. Then, the section explores the varied processes by which visual arts and performing arts organizations conduct marketing and discusses the key issues in their marketing processes, such as performing arts organizations’ market orientation and museums’ marketing strategies.
Tutorial: Conduct an in-class situation comedy, in which the topic is about fundraising or asking for money.

11. Marketing and Arts II: Market Research and Marketing Plan Making
After the introduction of cultural organization marketing approaches and strategies, this section follows it up with a discussion of the practical methods to put cultural organization marketing in place. Two issues are highlighted in this section: (1) the exploration of cultural consumers’ behaviors and the modes for their attendance, and (2) the methods of conducting market research (including market orientation research) and conceptualizing marketing plans based on the characteristics of cultural consumers and the market. Marketing schemes of performing art organizations and museums are also studied.
Tutorial: Discuss marketing approaches and strategies.
Assignment: Write Item 6 in the business plan.

12. Cultural Organization Performance Evaluation
How can cultural organization management be controlled and how can we measure the performances of cultural organizations? This section discusses the controlling system of cultural organizations, including internal and external controls as well as performance evaluation mechanisms. A general model that is applicable to a variety of cultural organizations for performance evaluation is presented first. Then, the methods for evaluating the performances of museum and performing art organizations are discussed. The section also introduces for performing art organizations a qualitative model from the perspective of the audience’s experiences. In terms of museum performance measurement, the section provides an evaluation model that comprises a range of indicators, including validity, reliability, feasibility, and externality.
Tutorial: Discuss cultural organization performance evaluation.
Assignment: Write Items 1 to 3, organize the materials for Item 9 in the business plan, and prepare the presentation for the group project.

13. Reviews and Discussions
Students are expected to deliver their group outputs, consisting of business plans with all the required elements in Byrne, 2009, pp. 32–33s. A guest judge from the professional field, together with the professor, will provide comments on the students’ works. Finally, the key points of this course are summarized to prepare students for quiz 2.

courses.title: Understanding Chinese Art through Exhibitions

meetings.location: William M W Mong Eng Bldg 408

courses.description: (UGED2286 is double-coded with CURE2406.)  The exhibition has become a site of knowledge production and a prominent and diverse part of contemporary culture. Regarding “Chinese art” as a social constructed concept, the course uses “exhibition” as an entry point to engage with issues concerning Chinese art and to explore the role played by exhibitions in the formation of the knowledge of Chinese art. It introduces the current theories and debates on the theory and history of exhibition, and the display methods, examining the changing concept of Chinese art and curatorial practices through detailed analysis of case studies. The first part of the course traces the formation of the concept of “Chinese art” by looking closely at the history of exhibitions on Chinese objects from the late Qing dynasty to the early twentieth century. The second part examines important exhibitions that have shaped our understanding of Chinese art. Structured thematically, the course discusses the curatorial concepts of selective significant international exhibitions on Chinese art, and investigate how scholarly research has been transformed into exhibitions which have shaped our understanding of Chinese art, constructed identity and been deployed for political ends.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon the completion of the course, students will be able to:

·Explain the theories of exhibition and the changing concepts of Chinese art

·Identify and describe the important exhibitions on Chinese art and prominent Chinese art objects.

·Identify and evaluate the curatorial ideas of important exhibitions on Chinese art.

·Select research materials and Chinese art objects to develop original research.

·Design and plan a virtual exhibition based on original research.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Curation in Arts and Culture
courses.description: “Curating,” a word that was once only used in museums, now has applications in everything in our lives, ranging from radio station DJs to almost all types of social media content. The popularity of the word reflects the growing importance of assembling, managing and presenting data and collection, a process of gathering information that brings maximum value relevant to different audiences.In this context, this course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to learn about both historical and contemporary examples of how culture is understood through exhibition design and curating. By covering various forms of curatorial traditions, disruptive ideas, and emergent digital practices in the ever-expanding field of curation, this course equips students with the ability to question what they take for granted and reflect on existing issues conducive to different cultures, values and beliefs. By the end of the course, students will be able to critically examine how knowledge is created inside and outside of art institutions and how curation could potentially become public knowledge.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students will be able to:

• Explain key historical and contemporary examples of exhibition design and curating, relating to a wider local and global context

• Examine critical issues concerning ways that different cultures, values and beliefs are represented through curation

• Develop skills to critically analyze how knowledge is created inside and outside art institutions

• Acquire personal and social competencies to transfer curating into knowledge sharing and act as an active agent in facilitating knowledge engagement

• Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by challenging assumptions in the ever-expanding field of curation

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Introduction to the Art Market
courses.description: The artworld is constructed through a network of individuals and institutions, all of which participate in con-tributing to the wider ecosystem of the global network and marketplace for art. The co-generative or mutu-ally constitutive nature between key players and institutions provides the context and rules for evaluating the aesthetic and economic value of art objects. In recent years, the art market has witnessed tremendous growth, and clusters of new galleries, global art fairs and auction houses have sprung up in cities within both developed and emerging economies, forming an ever-expanding network of art transitions, exhibi-tions, and causing an explosion of cultural activities amid various forms of urbanization. This course aims to provide students with theoretical knowledge and practical skills on how to identify the dynamic roles and activities of key players and institutions in the art market. It begins with an introduction to the history of art market, patronage system and art market logic. The, various practical skills are covered, including art valuation methods, techniques of buying and selling art, and agreements and laws that govern art transactions. In addition to practical skills, this course also encourages students to critically evaluate the complex relationships between the economy, aesthetic values and social behaviors within the global market-place. Special focus will be on emerging technologies and platforms concerning the global online art market.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing this course, students will be able to:

• Identify the roles and activities of key players and institutions in the art market

• Explain and analyze the history of the art market, patronage system and art market logic

• Develop skills in art valuation, the buying and selling of art, creating agreements and understanding the laws that govern art transactions

• Acquire personal and social competencies in connecting with the art community and pursuing future careers

• Develop skills in critical analysis concerning the complex relationships between the economy, aesthetic values and social behaviors within the global marketplace

• Develop an attitude of innovation and creativity by understudying emerging technologies and plat-forms concerning the global online art market

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Music, Culture and Outreach
courses.description: It is of crucial significance for cultural practitioners and managers to develop a solid foundation and capability in understanding the nature of music from various perspectives, as well as possessing the competency in appreciating the aesthetic and artistic value of musical works for the sake of advocating, marketing, coordinating and managing various programmes, events and outreach in music. Through exploring a wide range of music literature from different historical periods in music, the course focuses on three main perspectives:The first perspective focuses on listening and examining the major masterpieces in the history of music from Middle Ages to Modern, in which musical elements and characteristics of major forms and genres will be introduced and analysed. The second perspective is identified by the relationship of music to culture, in which the influence that cultural, social, political and religious events have exerted on music will be discussed. The third perspective focuses on experiencing and examining the approaches of music education in advocating music in the society. Through experiential learning, students will be able to develop basic knowledge and skills for applying the current theories and approaches in music education (e.g. play-based approach, Orff Schulwerk, Dalcroze, Kodaly) to outreach and education in the society.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Basics in Music Appreciation

1. What is “Music Appreciation”?

This session gives an introduction to how to be an ‘educated’ listener’. Major elements and focus of listening in appreciating the aesthetic and artistic value of music will be introduced.

2. Roles of Music in the Society

This session discusses the roles of music in the society and various impacts of music will be discussed. Also, this section investigates how cultural, social, political and religious events have influenced the development of music.

3. Understanding Orchestration

This session uses musical excerpts and examples to illustrate the characteristics and timbre/tone colour of a wide range of orchestral instruments, as well as various concepts on orchestration.

4. Field Trip

Field trip to a music institution (e.g. orchestra) will be arranged for students to gain a deeper understanding on the various aspects of performance as well as management of music institutions.

Part II: A Journey to Appreciating Music

5. Music in Middle Ages (500-1400) and Renaissance (1450-1600)

This session introduces the main characteristics of Middle Ages and Renaissance music. Major genres and musical styles of the Middle Ages will be discussed, e.g. Gregorian Chant, Mass, Estampe, Rondeau. Featured genres in the Renaissance will also be discussed, e.g. Motet, Mass, Madrigal, Lute Song, Polychoral Motet. Through exploring the musical works of Middle Ages and Renaissance, the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.

6. Music in the Baroque Period (1600-1750)

This session studies the main characteristics and musical style of Baroque music. Major forms and genres of Baroque music will be introduced and analysed, e.g. Opera, Solo Concerto, Prelude and Fugue, Cantata, Oratorio, Suite. Through exploring the musical works of Baroque period, the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.

7. Music in the Classical Period (1750-1820)

This session studies the main characteristics and musical style of Classical Period. Major forms and genres of Baroque music will be introduced and analysed, e.g. sonata form, theme and variation, rondo, classical symphony, classical concerto.

8. Music in the Romantic Period (1820-1900)

This session studies the main characteristics of Romantic period. Romantic art songs, operas, programme music, and instrumental works will be introduced and analysed. Through exploring the musical works of Classical period, the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.

9. Modern Music (1900-Present)/Music of Non-Western Cultures

This session studies the main characteristics of modern music. For example, expressionism, impressionism, 20th century nationalism, and Jazz music will be introduced and analysed. This session also examines the characteristics, musical styles, genres, instrumentation of music from non-western culture, e.g. music in sub-Saharan Africa, classical music of India, Koto music of Japan. Through exploring music of non-western cultures and the musical works of modern period , the interrelationship among music, culture and society will be discussed.

Part III: Bringing the Joy of Appreciating Music through Education

10. Current Theories and Practices in Music Education

This session focuses on discussing the current theories, thoughts, and approaches in music education, e.g. Developmentally Appropriate Practice (DAP), Play-Based Approach, Orff Schulwerk, and Dalcroze Approach. The application of these approaches and theories to music appreciation activities in outreach programmes will be discussed.

11. Workshop in Music Pedagogies (I)

Through experiential learning and firsthand experience, this session introduces the skills and techniques in movement and choreography for conducting outreach and education in music. Musical excerpts discussed in Part II will be used as examples for illustration.

12. Workshop in Music Pedagogies (II)

Through experiential learning and firsthand experience, this session introduces the skills and techniques in singing and chanting, and the application of percussion instruments for conducting outreach and education in music. Musical excerpts discussed in Part II will be used as examples for illustration.

13. Presentation and Conclusion

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Visual Arts Management
courses.description: This course leads students to study various modes and philosophies of visual arts management undertaken in different venues. Aesthetics and art criticisms are critical in directing art interpretation and presentation. Contemporary management of visual arts responds predominantly to the worldwide discussions on modernism as well as various post-modernist writings. In addition, it has to operate in accordance with the prescribed state policy. For this bilateral concern of art management, the course comprises two sections. The first section leads students to study the writings on aesthetics by critics from Plato to Foucault, whose arguments are still valid in inspiring many art exhibitions. The second section discusses the practical concerns and techniques in maximizing the social and economic impacts of art exhibitions and relevant events. Both sections discuss case studies taken from different parts of the world.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to describe different categories of visual arts in professional language; to define and explain the key terms in visual art literature; to appreciate and analyze art exhibitions with reference to intellectual debates on aesthetics; to describe and explain the art policies implemented in East Asia and the West; and to develop independent thinking on the operation and promotion of art organizations.
courses.course_syllabus:
Section I: Aesthetics and art criticisms

1. Introduction: Shifting perspectives on visual art management in the 20th century
Visual art management was a new discipline born in late 19th century when museums appeared in Europe. This session reviews the early practices in museum curatorship and its transformations under the impact of modernism. It explains how the focus in managing visual art shifted from scholarly field to public arena in the 21st century.

2. ‘Is it good art?’: From Plato, Hume to Danto on aesthetics
‘What is beauty?’ has been the most discussed topic in Western art history since the times of Plato. This session discusses the canonical writings by Plato and his followers and critics during the times of Renaissance. The discussion links to their contributions to the post-modern theories that still weigh importantly today.

3. Visuality and Perception
The intention of artists and the perception of arts of the beholders are core issues in Western aesthetics. This section discusses the most well-read writings by Ernest Gombrich and John Berger, who respond to the question as to whether arts comprise social values.

4. ‘Does Fine Arts still stand today?’: From fine arts to commercial arts
Visual arts comprise a wide range of categories today that include both traditional oil paintings and sculpture, as well as contemporary art forms that includes installation, and industrial designs. This section discusses the shifting definitions of arts and the incorporation of commercial arts in exhibitions.

5. Cross-cultural aesthetics
Are Western art theories applicable to the Asian contexts? Correlation exists between civilization and visual culture. This session discusses the Chinese visual art system and explains its difference from that in the West.

Section II: Concerns and Practices

6. Writing and arts
This lecture analyzes different texts about visual arts taken from museum exhibition catalogues, auction house catalogues, newspaper reviews, as well as commercial gallery publications. This leads students to reflect on the different presentations of arts for education and commercial purposes.

7. Arts and state
This lectures discusses the various policies implemented in the US, UK, and China that enables or hinders the developments of art organizations and individual artists.

8. Business and Arts
Artists and art organizations s management relies heavily on the patronage of business firm. This session discuss the mutual relationship between arts and business, as well as their shifting roles in recent decades.

9. Audience and arts
This lecture extends the discussion of the last, and focuses on the concerns and strategies of art and cultural promoters in non-profit, educational sectors. This introduces the issue of branding implemented in many world renowned institutes and evaluates their success.

10. Managers and arts
This lecture discusses human resources management in the art industry. Examples of excellent directorship taken from the UK and US will be studied to shed light on the significance of professional leadership in the discipline.

11. The Biennial fever
Bienne is world recognized art event to showcase and acknowledge the achievements of young artists. This lecture discusses the organization and social impacts of the bienne festivals held in Europe and Asia.

12. Artist villages
Artist village is developing everywhere in the world. This lectures discusses the examples found in China and Taiwan and leads students to think whether Hong Kong will need an artist cluster for future cultural developments.

13. Art events and festivals
Annual art events and festivals serve as major strategies to generate social and economic support for art today. This lecture discusses the organization and planning of those events and evaluate the examples taken from Europe, US and Asia.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Performing Arts Management
courses.description: This course discusses the missions, administrations, and strategies of performing art organizations. Since the 1950s, performing art managers have realized the significance of efficient management in achieving popularity and sale. This course will go through the general topics as to how the performing art organizations are administered in national and legal terms; how they solicit funding; how they are operated in terms of ticketing and touring; and how they are strategically promoted for both branding and social benefits.
courses.learning_outcomes: Upon completion of the course, students will be able to describe the practical concerns of the performing art organizations in terms of their daily operation; to identify various sources of funding in support of performing arts; to evaluate the administration structure and strategies undertaken in different countries; and describe and explain the different policies implemented in East Asia and the West.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Profit-making vs Non-profiting making performing houses
This lecture introduces the basic, binal division between two different types of performing houses. This leads students to reflect on the confliciting aims between the two types, and realize the significance of the overlapping features of the two.

2. Setting up the ‘mission’
Clear directorship is recognizedly important among performing arts management. This lecture analyzes the various mission statements and approach of the performing houses in Europe, US and China. This discusses how a mission statement is being written up and executed.

3. Legal rights and obligations of non-profit making organizations.
This lecture discusses the legal terms of the non-profiting making performing organizations, and provides an in-depth study towards their social obligations in exchange for tax exemption.

4. Commercial productions.
This lecture discusses the concerns and strategies of Broadway productions. Examples of programming and touring techniques of the theatres in the US, France and China will be discussed.

5. Budget planning
Financial management in the performing industry aims to maintain balance between expenses and revenue. This lecture discusses the management of book keeping, payroll taxes, facilities maintenance, and auditing.

6. Fund-raising possibilities for non-profit performing houses
There are many fund-raising opportunities for non-profit organizations. Managers usually have to work closely with the Board of Directors. Tactics in securing interests and long-term partnerships with external and potential donors will be discussed.

7. Sale and ticketing
Following up with the last session, this lecture discusses the marketing management of commercial productions. The role of ticket office and various advertising skills will be compared and discussed.

8. Performing arts and education
This lecture discusses the American tactics in engaging junior and high school students in performing arts. It discusses the experience of the New York City Centre and the Kennedy Centre. This session invites students to reflect on the social impacts of the performing industry through arts education.

9. Human resources
Theatres and Orchestras work closely with large numbers of members from various sorts of backgrounds. Management in labor relations has always been a key to achieve success in the performing industry. This section introduces various labour unions and legal regulations towards employment contracts.

10. Touring production
Touring is a common tactic employed to increase revenue by taking the performing crew overseas. However, touring means many risks that may increase expenses. This lecture discusses the benefits and shortcomings in taking a production on a tour.

11. Facility management
Facilities maintenance assumes a large share of expense on the financial sheet of presenters. This session discusses the contracting tactics in keeping the costs low. In addition, it also discusses event programming that draws attention to the management of facilities.

12. Internship and youth programmes
This lecture discusses the outreach options for performing houses. It will focus on the networking and partnership formed on the basis of short-term internship; and on the audience-engaging programme that develops the audience base of different age range.

13. Presentation
Student presentation of group project.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Film and Literature: Inter-Media Studies
courses.description: This course's objective is to acquaint students with the kindred relationships between film and literature as well as to help them develop a more critical awareness to appreciate these two media from a cultural studies perspective. It will cover the following topics: introduction to the art of film, the generic and mediumistic comparisons of film and literature: film and the novel or film and drama or the theatre, etc.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Learning Outcomes

Students are expected to develop interdisciplinary perspectives to understand and be critical of the following:

- Cultural production, circulation, and consumption are ideologically and economically linked.

- Community preservation and regeneration, cultural diversity, and cultural participation are important in the building of a better society.

Students are expected to develop the following skills and values:

- Ability in critically analyzing the diversity of values and interests in society

- Literacy in different forms of visual and verbal expression, understanding how meanings and affects are constructed in different media forms and genres

- Ability in drawing on a number of disciplinary origins within areas of the arts, humanities and social sciences to appreciate the richness and the usefulness of interdisciplinary approach
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 ) Course Introduction

From a novel to a film (about media)

Survival for fitness (about life)

- Breakdown of the boundary between film and literature, science and art, nature and culture, reality and fiction, life and text, text and context, theory and (filmic and literary) text, high and low.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Animals, Culture and Modern Society
courses.description: (UGEC3481 is double-coded with CURE3003.)  How do we understand and connect to animal kingdom?How do human-animal connections shape modern culture and society?How do cultural studies and humanities expand our scope on animal and nature?Culture is ordinary, in Raymond William’s saying, but the ordinariness is merely treated as a reflection of human everyday life. Although cultural studies has sustained concern on everyday life with mass production, consumerism, sexism, racism and postmodernism, the discipline always lags behind the concern of nature and animal species. As the issues of animal abuse, environmental protection, factory farming, animal protection policy and law-making, as well as media various portrayals being the hot topics of our (post)modern world, the study of animal with the perspective of cultural studies and other humanity disciplines can explore the possibilities of better human-animal relationship. This course is designed with an empathic concern of other-than-human animals. By exploring different issues of human and animals’ life, this course looks for a harmonious balance of nature and modern culture.This course focuses on three areas, through which we can explore the different aspects of animal and cultural studies. These areas are:A. Entering Jurassic Park – Remaking Animals in Leisure (Lecture A1-A4)B. Attacking Godzilla – Representing Animals in Media (Lecture B1-B4)C. Finding Nemo – Revitalizing Animals in the City  (Lecture C1-C4)Each area covers a set of animal issue discussion. Area A, apart from theorizing animal with cultural studies, tackles the basic animal issues: pet-nurturing, zoo-building, forest-sustaining and tourism. This is to provide a foundation for understanding animals with a critical reflection of everyday life. Area B, set with the concern of media, discusses issues of animal representation in cartoon, cinema, literature and journalism. This is to read how animals would be represented and how this affects human understanding and related policy-making. A screening will be run after Lecture Area B. This is to provide an alternative understanding of animal representation in popular media. Area C further deals with the matters of animal-city relationship in seeing how dogs and cats, cattle and swine, and fishes and dolphins are (mal)treated in the street, the farm and the sea respectively. This is to end the course with a leading thought of perfect balance of nature and modernity; and more queries of human-animal relationship will be raised for contemplation.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Gender and Sexuality in Cultural Studies
courses.description: What is gender and why does it matter? What are the significances and limitations of gender as an analytic category? How are dominant understandings and practices of gender constructed and contested in different cultural forms and social contexts? This course is divided into three sections. The first section introduces the basic vocabulary of gender studies and how gender intersects with other forms of differences. The second section explores gender through various cultural products and media (e.g. literature, film, video games, theatre, social activism, etc.) The final section examines key debates in relation to gender in specific social contexts. Upon completion of this course, students would understand basic theoretical concepts for gender analysis and key debates on gender as well as gain the ability to think critically about gender.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Learning outcomes

Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

1) understand basic theoretical concepts for gender analysis and debates on gender

2) analyze how gender intersects with other forms of differences

3) use the key concepts and theories to analyze a specific cultural phenomenon from a gendered perspective

4) critically think about gender

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Globalization and Cultural Production
courses.description: This course investigates the multifaceted relationships between globalization and culture. Under the influence of globalization and increasing international trade, are we leading more diverse or homogenous lifestyles? Does globalization promote or hamper cultural changes? Why do the commercial world and cultural theorists read globalization so differently? In this course we will investigate how the developing global culture is influencing our daily lives from the perspectives of national and cultural identity, information society, consumerism, popular culture, etc. Emphasizing both theory and its application in analysing different kinds of texts (e.g., literature, films, maps, fashions, theme parks, shopping malls, etc.), we will discuss the changing meanings of citizenship, mobilization, technology, capital, space, and time under the influence of globalization.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Students are expected to develop interdisciplinary perspectives to understand and be critical of the following:
Our regional, national, and global orders are made up of and maintained by cultural practices, expressions, and meanings.
Cultural production, circulation, and consumption are ideologically and economically linked.

2) Students are expected to develop the following skills and values:
Inter-cultural sensitivity and respect
A balance of local and global perspectives
Ability in critically analyzing the diversity of values and interests in society

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Technoscience and Culture
courses.description: We are now experiencing fast developments in technoscience in the modern world. As everything turns electronic and hi-tech, e.g., email, ebanking, ecommerce, plus the newly developed sciences such as cloning, biogenetic engineering, etc., it is important to introduce to students the ways technosciences and mass media bear on our sense of identity and subjectivity. The aim of this course is to help students make sense of different ramifications of contemporary technosciences which have unprecedentedly transformed their everyday life experiences, in other words, to introduce them to the study of technoscience culture. Through a body of fiction, films, T.V. shows, computer mediated communication devices, cybercultural forms (VR and AI), etc., which deal directly with new communication technologies, this class will highlight the radical effects on the centrality of visual culture in the modern world, on the post-modernist self and on virtuality of all kinds.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1) Students are expected to develop interdisciplinary perspectives to understand and be critical of the following:
Cultural industries and institutions play a key role to shape our collective identity, taste, and values.
Cultural production, circulation, and consumption are ideologically and economically linked.

2) Students are expected to develop the following skills and values:
Ability in critically analyzing the diversity of values and interests in society
Literacy in different forms of visual and verbal expressions, understanding how meanings and affects are constructed in different media forms and genres
Ability in drawing on a number of disciplinary origins within areas of the arts, humanities and social sciences to appreciate the richness and the usefulness of interdisciplinary approach

courses.description: The emerging culture is taking place in the virtual world. courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Cultural and Creative Industries
courses.description: This course aims to introduce Cultural and Creative Industries (including design, fashion, advertising, art, antiques and crafts, film and video, games and animation, music, performing arts, publishing, television and radio, etc.) to undergraduate students. The course serves to stimulate interests in understanding the creative process in these industries and how they as a whole contribute to social, cultural and economic growth. Students will be required to attend guest lectures, field visits as well as other exhibitions or events related to the cultural and creative industries as prescribed by the course tutor.
courses.learning_outcomes: In terms of knowledge acquisition, students are expected to understand how culture and creativity is contributing to the development of society in terms of the make-up of our regional, national and global orders; their role in the shaping of cultural practices, expressions and ideology; their relations to production and enterprising and hence their role in the shaping of our identity, taste and values as well as economy and policies. In terms of values and skills, students are expected to develop critical ability in analyzing the diversity of values and interests, inter-cultural sensitivity, a balance view of local and global issues, literacy in understanding different visual and textual meanings and forms and the ability to appreciate the importance and significance of the inter-disciplinary nature of cultural and creative industries.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Cultural Criticism Workshop
courses.description: Introduce students to various disciplines of cultural criticism, from literature, film, urban cultures, art performances and policies, etc. and a blend of all these. Different approaches of cultural criticism will be practised, from textual, formalistic to ideological ones, realizing each power and limitation. Writing styles (e.g. interpretive, provocative, deconstructive, prescriptive) and the related critics' roles will be examined too. Students will be encouraged to put their understanding of cultural theory in general to current cultural issues happening in the society at large. Both reading and writing will be stressed, with the aim of enlarging their reading scope (e.g. from local to China Mainland to foreign media) and enriching their hands-on writing experience.
courses.learning_outcomes:
To bridge the gap of cultural theory and cultural practice
To sharpen students’ sensitivity about cultural issues and phenomena both locally and globally, and develop their own viewpoints beyond information level
To enhance students’ writing abilities, especially for written media like cultural magazines or newspapers
To enhance students’ understanding of the praxis of cultural industry.
To channel students’ participation in public sphere both as readers and writers. Quality writings will be referred to local media for publication, through cooperation established with local media and institutions. Another option is to publish students’ quality writings as a collection, self-funded or by other publication co. (I can act as the editorial supervisor in this case).

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: The Politics and Culture of Nationalisms
courses.description: Nationalism is a major world-wide response to the increasingly globalized world, which witnesses an exponential increase in the movement of capital, labor, commodities, cultures and ideas, yet has threatened established ways of life and rendered states and peoples vulnerable to economic pressures. This course provides a broad overview of the theories of and approaches to the study of nationalist thoughts and practices. It understands nationalism's emergence and its endurance as a major cultural politics in a globalized world. It explores nationalism as it is linked to various modern socio-political and cultural effects: national consciousness, ethnic and identity conflicts, state building, nationalist ideologies and nationalist movements. It examines the politics of nationalism and ethnicity with reference to experiences in developing societies in Asia in the course of colonial encounters and in post-colonial contexts. It examines the various ways in which politics of nationalism has influenced economic modernization, globalization, gender relations, social conflicts, cultural citizenship debates and post-colonial struggles.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completion of this course, student will be able to

1. understand the theoretical basis of modern nationalism in general

2. understand the major ways in which modern nationalism developed in the history of post-colonial nations in Asia

3. understand the role of culture in the politics of nationalism

4. enhance their critical and analytical thinking on contemporary topics of national politics, conflicts, tradition and identity.

5. enhance their ability in academic discussion and analytical writing.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Film and Cultural Politics in Southeast Asia
courses.description: (UGEC3482 is double-coded with CURE3033.) This course is a survey of Southeast Asian cinema read against the backdrop of its distinct historical, political, ecological, and cultural conditions. Initially a Cold War construct comprising Singapore, Indonesia, Thailand, the Philippines, Vietnam, Malaysia, Cambodia, Brunei, Laos, and Timor-Leste, the term ‘Southeast Asia’ has come to refer to a highly complex and pluralistic region of over 660 million people, 25,000 islands, and 150 ethnolinguistic communities. With its national identities formed from the encounter with and struggle against American, British, French, Dutch, Hispanic, Indian, Japanese, and Chinese influence, Southeast Asia’s movies have served as venues for propaganda and resistance. This course looks at how the remediations of different genres such as noir, melodrama, western, and sci-fi tackle controversial issues of gender, race, religion, poverty, migration, and the environment. Instead of smoothening the continuity of official historical narratives, it uncovers how documentaries, epics, and horror reexamine the trauma of past colonization, authoritarianism, and violence. To conclude, the course explores how television serials, anthology films, and online databases trace nascent cross-border and intra-regional communities beyond the limits of sovereignty.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

1. To become acquainted with the key filmmakers, works, themes, and issues in Southeast Asian cinema
2. To explain how film and media representations visualize and problematize the distinct social, economic, political, and historical conditions of diverse Southeast Asian cultures
3. To apply a comparative, transnational lens to examine film and media representations that illustrate how these diverse Southeast Asian cultures have become articulated in Hong Kong
courses.course_syllabus:
* *Week 1: Visualizing Southeast Asia**

* How do scholars, filmmakers, and artists imagine Southeast Asia?

* *Week 2: Inter-Orientalism**

* How have commercial movies, television shows, and tourism campaigns visualized the landscapes and populations of Southeast Asia with an orientalist gaze?

* *Week 3: Remediating Genres**

* How does Southeast Asian cinema reinvent the generic conventions of Western, spy, martial arts, and science fiction films?

* *Week 4: Crime Noir and Slum Voyeurism**

* How do film noir, crime thrillers, and poverty porn characterize the settings of Southeast Asian megalopolises with destitution, squalor, and violence?

* *Week 5: Racial Border-Crossings**

* How does Southeast Asian cinema ruminate on issues of race and multiculturalism?

* *Week 6: Migrant Labor Mobilities**

* How do melodramas and documentaries spotlight the victimization of migrant workers?

* *Week 7: Ghosts, Monsters, and Spiritualities**

* How do ghost, monster, and horror movies explore the link between spirituality and development?

* *Week 8: Historical Memory**

* How do period epics and experimental films construct and reexamine historical representations?

* *Week 9: Documentary Trauma**

* How do reflexive documentaries explore the trauma of political violence in Southeast Asia?

* *Week 10: Stardom**

* How have popular movie stars in Southeast Asia shaped social identity?

* *Week 11: Theaters and Spaces**

* How do cinema and historiography represent the spaces of film distribution and exhibition?

* *Week 12: Seriality and Regionalism**

* How do omnibus films, serial dramas, and digital artworks imagine a pan-regional community?

* *Week 13: Field trip to sites in Hong Kong with historical or cultural significance to Southeast Asia**

* Possible destinations include the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Museum, Kowloon City, and Filipinas Heritage Trail.

* *Week 14: Presentation and submission of paper**

* As a synthesis of the class materials and discussions for the entire semester, the final paper will examine the film and media culture of Southeast Asia in Hong Kong. Students can opt to work on the final paper individually, in pairs, or in groups. Possible topics include how Vietnamese boat people, Filipino and Indonesian domestic workers, Burmese Buddhist monks, or Kowloon City’s Thai community are visualized in Hong Kong’s cinema, news, advertising, and social media.

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Korean Media and Popular Culture
courses.description: (UGEC3483 is double-coded with CURE3034.)This course aims to introduce Korean society and culture through Korean Popular Culture in relation to media and cultural studies scholarship and its socio-cultural contexts. In particular, we will examine the meaning of media and culture and its social changes in contemporary Korea through exploring various emerging trends and cultural studies as methodological tool within modern and contemporary Korean issues. Global popularity of Korean popular culture and the transnational Hallyu (Korean Wave) boom continue to percolate beyond Asia and inspire various critical questions regarding trans-nationalism, cultural imperialism and musical authenticity and hybridity. The course readings engage wide range of various issues and arguments of media and cultural studies scholarship as methodological tools; such as cultural representation, meaning of hegemony, cultural industry/economy and globalism of media, post colonialism, audience of mass media and fandom culture, gender and queer issues, and then further focus on the specific context of Korean popular culture including the pivotal notions of colonial modernity, Japanese imperialism, cultural hegemony in colonial Korea, meaning of Americanization, issues of popular memory and decolonization discourses, nationalism and globalization and Korean Wave, body/gender/sexuality / LGBTQ issue in Korean Media and Popular culture, cyber culture and internet memes, transnationalism and diaspora issues and its aftermath. We actively discuss various audio-visual artifacts including Korean news, music video, films, TV dramas, and pop music in each class in order to understand better the texts and contexts within the historical and sociocultural paradigm of recent sociology, media/communication studies scholarship.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Torecognize various conceptual ideas and critical thinking on comprehensive Korean media and popular culture and major issues and historical incidents in relation to modernity, coloniality, Americanisation/Americanism, globalization in Korean popular culture.
2. To explain how Korean media and popular culture and its cultural representation and industrial system reflect and resonate with the various socio-economic, political, colonial/postcolonial conditions of globalized Korean popular culture
3. To appropriate glocal and transnational critical perspectives to examine various Korean media and popular culture and its cultural representations that illustrate how these diverse Korean media and popular culture have become articulated in the global context

courses.subject: CURE
courses.title: Contemporary Art and Representation
courses.description: Contemporary art has emerged as a privileged domain for exploring interspecies relations where various contemporary issues intersect. Thus, this course aims to introduce contemporary art and its representational aesthetics to consider various socio-cultural issues regarding art circulation and its interpretation, the connotation of contemporary art in society. The works of various contemporary artists will be presented in the context of focal issues that invoke social practices, conventional modality of contemporary art scene, shifting art interpretation within the norms and values in a society, relational art and public engagement, experimental use of media. In each week we will analyze contemporary art with specific themes, emphasizing the recurrent motifs and issues in contemporary art and its politics of representation, such as situation and activism, space, ruin and urbanity/modernity, trauma and memory in history, animality and non-human subjectivity, post-human and prosthetic body, gender and sexuality, queer art, magic (the material culture of the weird and eerie, ghost and monstrous iconography), cuteness as a concept reflecting from the contemporary popular cultural reference. Close readings in both academic and art critical practices, class discussion and participation will culminate in a final individual research paper interrogating the implications of representational tactics and strategies of a single artist and/or artwork in contemporary art.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, students should be able to:

1) Become acquainted with various conceptual ideas and critical thinking on contemporary art and its representation in terms of cultural literacy and practice of art analysis, interpretation, and evaluation

2) Develop students’ art practice with theory and critical analysis to form new ways of responding to the contemporary art and to interrogate the meaning of contemporary art in relation to urgent socio-political contexts

3) Introduce various research-driven artists and their urgent relation to socio-political contexts specializing in critical, speculative, and social art practices, moving image, performance, and visual aesthetics
